PETITION.TITLE: Elector-initiated Referendum
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill of citizen initiated constitution and legislative referenda, and voters veto.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will pass said Bill so that a national referendum can be held on this matter, with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.

PETITION.TITLE: Helsham Inquiry

That the Federal Government decision to ban future development in 80 per cent of the Helsham inquiry area and rob Tasmanians of hundreds of jobs in the forest and associated industries is wholly unacceptable.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the Federal Government abide by the majority decision of the Helsham inquiry.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat; and

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medications needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should read the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park; and

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The gold mining industry is a vibrant expanding industry which provides employment for many Australians;
The gold mining industry provides valuable export income which contributes to a stronger balance of trade and Australian dollar, and thus a higher standard of living for all Australians;
The Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining represents a threat to an industry which is vital to Australia's future; and
We call on the Federal Government to withdraw its proposal for a tax on gold.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia showeth:

(1) The adoption of the upgraded Tax-File Number proposal, to compel every person to quote the number for many ordinary business dealings, would be an intrusion on the traditional liberty we have enjoyed under the Common Law and the Parliamentary Federation in our Constitutional Monarchy.

(2) The databanks and surveillance methods that would increase under this proposal would tend to provide a constant unwarranted threat to the privacy of citizens, residents, and perhaps visitors and tourists.

(3) There are other parallel threats to our privacy and liberties, such as the move to give police in Australia and overseas access to our Income Tax File details, and to provide computer-based information to an international bureau in Brussels, plus the proposal that State police be empowered to listen in to private telephone conversations.

Therefore your petitioners pray that the Government withdraw any bill, or repeal any Act, to establish the Tax-File Number proposal, and that Members of Parliament, without regard for party, unanimously reject any such moves as being contrary to our personal liberties, our privacy, and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aborigines: Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia is one nation which comprises people from many different racial and cultural backgrounds;
That a Treaty with one of these peoples-the Aborigines-would be divisive and would be equivalent to the setting up of a separate nation;
That a Treaty could lead to the introduction of a national system of land rights;
That we are totally opposed to the signing of a Treaty with the Aboriginal people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate should ensure that Australia Post maintains a postal service in the town of Low Head.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Centralised Databanks
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

that the Australia Card Bill has revealed that the unnecessary existence of centralised data banks in Canberra under control of the Health Insurance Commission, the Department of Social Security and others, presents to the people of Australia a constant and unwarranted threat to their privacy, to their basic human rights in a free society, and that the proposed Cash Transactions Bill 1987 and the intention to create a single, national register of births, deaths and marriages will further exacerbate the situation.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE (SAFE AND UNIMPEDED ACCESS FOR VISITING FOREIGN WARSHIPS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Newman) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to establish procedures to enable visiting foreign warships to obtain safe and unimpeded access to Australian ports, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Newman) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that in future the Federal Government discharges its responsibilities in relation to visits by foreign warships. As senators will by now be fully aware, last weekend, on the occasion of the Bicentennial Naval Salute in Melbourne, the Seamen's Union of Australia, endorsed by the Trades Hall Council, adopted a resolution to ban tugs from assisting United States and British ships because of the believed nuclear capacity of the ships. As a result of such action, the British aircraft carrier Ark Royal and its supply ship Fort Grange were prevented from berthing in Melbourne, whilst the USS Ingersoll, having docked under its own steam, was unable to leave Melbourne without assistance because of bad weather. All of this and not a word of apology from the Victorian State Government.

Clearly the Federal Government needs to be reminded of just how important the visits to Australian ports by foreign warships are to Australia's international relations, and of the obvious and vital implications such visits have for our national defence and security. Apparently the Government also needs to be reminded that it is their responsibility, not the states', to maintain Australia's defence and international arrangements. For not only did the events of last weekend reveal the Government's weakness in kow-towing to the extremist Victorian unions. After all, weakness is nothing new for this Government. More importantly, the whole episode revealed a dangerous willingness on the part of the Government to sacrifice the defence and security of all Australians in favour of the dictates of an extremist minority.

Australia is, after all, an island, and the sea is therefore one of our first lines of defence. And when we consider the current political and military instability of our closer neighbours-Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Fiji and New Caledonia for example, as well as our own limited naval capability to defend our shores and sea lanes, such treatment as our Western Allies received last weekend is nothing short of irresponsible. The friendship and military support of our Western Allies is a vital necessity for the defence of this nation. To try that friendship is to tamper with Australia's defence. Such an episode must never happen again. To this end, in addition to reminding the Government of its responsibilities and powers in the area of visiting foreign warships, the Bill will make provision in formal terms for the authorising, on behalf of Australia, of entry to our waters by foreign warships where such entry is desired, and it will provide a legal framework for appropriate action to be taken to safeguard approved visits from obstruction and interference.

As regards the policy of foreign governments to `neither confirm nor deny' the carriage of nuclear arms aboard their warships, surely the Government recognizes a necessity for these countries to safeguard against the disclosure of valuable information to potential enemies about the military capabilities of the particular ship, and of the country itself? Against this background I turn to the terms of the Bill. As I have already mentioned, the Bill includes an objects clause stating that it is intended to establish procedures for the discharge by the Commonwealth of its constitutional responsibilities and powers. The clause also declares the intention that in furthering the object of the Act the cooperation and assistance of the States and their authorities be sought and utilised, so far as it is appropriate and practicable to do so, in facilitating access to Australian ports for warships visiting Australia. However, the Bill is expressed to operate to the exclusion of any State or Territory laws that would prevent or obstruct any act or thing that a warship or person is empowered or permitted to do by the Bill.

Central to the operation of the legislation is the power given to the Minister for Defence to grant approval for a specified foreign warship, or class of foreign warships, to have access during a specified period to Australian ports or to specified Australian ports. Such an approval may be made subject to conditions. It is envisaged that, in practice, all such approvals will be subject to compliance with conditions relating to navigation and safety, health, quarantine, customs and immigration requirements. Provision is also made for the Minister to give directions to the commander of a foreign warship in respect of which an approval is in force. Directions may be given about the movement of the ship or its crew or about the loading or unloading of goods. Directions of this nature would essentially be supplementary to the conditions attached to an approval, and could be necessitated by circumstances arising after an approval is given. Where an approval is in force, a foreign warship covered by the approval will be entitled to enter, remain in and depart from an Australian port covered by the approval. In addition, goods may be loaded onto or unloaded from the ship and services may be supplied to the ship.

Under clause 9 of the Bill, the Minister for Defence is empowered to give directions to facilitate access by a foreign warship to an Australian port, where a relevant approval is in force. These powers would be exercised only as a last resort where access by a foreign warship was being frustrated or significantly hindered by a refusal or failure to provide the goods, services or facilities normally required for that purpose. These might include the provision of pilotage or tug services, the availability or berthing facilities, or the supply of services such as water or electricity. Clause 9 provides that a direction may be given only where the Minister is satisified that giving the direction is necessary to secure the entry, stay or departure of the ship, or the safety of the ship, its crew or other persons, or is necessary or convenient for the effective operation of the ship. Provision is made for the compensation for loss or damage sustained as a result of compliance with a direction. Provision is also made for payment for the provision of goods, services or facilities, or other things, pursuant to a direction.

The Bill will establish offences of preventing, hindering or obstructing the entry of a ship to, the berthing of a ship at, or the departure of a ship from, an Australian port in respect of which a relevant approval is in force. Other offences are provided relating to failure to comply with a direction by the Minister for Defence under clause 9, and of preventing, hindering or obstructing other specified activities relating to a ship. As I have already said, the Opposition believes that visits to Australian ports by the warships of our friends and allies have the overwhelming support of the Australian people. The Opposition is also confident that this legislation, prompted by threat to the continuance of such visits, will have similar support. Even now, these visiting warships, here at the invitation of the Federal Government to help us celebrate our Bicentenary, are waiting to visit further Australian ports. The Government is lacking the leadership and the determination to enable these visits to take place. It is urgent that this legislation be considered by this Parliament. I therefore commend the Bill to the Senate.

SALES TAX ASSESSMENT (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

This Bill will amend the sale value provisions of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) so that where a manufacturer sells goods only by retail, after 8 p.m. on Tuesday 23 August 1988 the sale value for tax purposes will be based on the manufacturer's own costs and profit. At present, where a manufacturer sells goods only by retail the sale value is based on the price charged by another manufacturer selling identical goods by wholesale. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The Treasurer has announced, as part of the 1988-89 Budget, a number of changes to the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system. This Bill, and one other I will introduce shortly, will amend the sales tax law to give effect to those changes. The changes will, with one exception, come into effect after 8 p.m. on Tuesday 23 August 1988. The exception is the announcement concerning the imposition of sales tax on beer, which will come into effect on 24 August 1988. Given the comments already made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech and the details contained in Statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1 and the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable senators, I will do no more than outline briefly the changes proposed.

First, as part of the announced reforms to the beer excise, currently exempt beer with an alcohol content of more than 1.15 per cent by volume is to be taxed at the rate of 20 per cent. Secondly, the Bill will correct as follows a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the various schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. All plastic envelopes, courier type bags and all goods used by retailers to wrap or secure goods for marketing or delivery, which are currently exempt from tax, will become taxable at the rate of 20 per cent. The tax payable on wrapping materials marketed for household use will increase from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. The following exempt goods will become taxable at the 10 per cent rate. All containers, spoons, serviettes and accessories used by retailers in marketing take-away foodstuffs; mixes marketed for use in the manufacture of thick shakes and ice cream; and museli bars and other health food bars.

The rate of tax on toiletries, perfumes and cosmetics, and on photographs and photographic materials, will be reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. All aircraft except gliders are to be exempt from tax. Food for fish and crustaceans farmed for commercial purposes, which is currently taxable at the 20 per cent rate, is to be exempt from tax. Soy milk which is currently taxable at the 20 per cent rate is to be exempt if it does not contain flavouring, and taxable at the 10 per cent rate if flavoured. Finally, the Bill will confirm the scope of the law in relation to the taxation of flavoured milk drinks and bathroom fittings and sanitary ware. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday of this week we were debating whether there should be a cognate debate on the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and the Australian Democrats' notice of motion for the establishment of a Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia. Mr President, if I may, I will give a brief resume of where we got to at the time. This Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 seeks to introduce uniform registrations in the use and registration of veterinary and agricultural chemicals throughout Australia. A motion was moved by the Australian Democrats to debate the Bill cognately with a notice of motion for the establishment of an inquiry into the use of all agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: However, Mr President, I believe that if two Bills or, in this case, a Bill and a notice of motion are to be debated cognately, they should have a certain amount of common purpose. I do believe, and I certainly maintain, that there is not very much common purpose about these two questions that are before honourable senators at present. If they are not in total unison, at least they should have something in common. I can find nothing they have in common.

Perhaps I should give a brief resume of the objects of the Bill. The objectives of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill are to protect and enhance trade and commerce in agricultural produce and livestock; to assist in the conduct of agricultural and veterinary operations in all or any of the States or Territories; to minimise any undue hazard-this is the important one-to the public, the environment, users and agricultural produce and livestock from the application of chemical products in accordance with recommendations for their use; to minimise the need for separate evaluation of chemical products by registering authorities of States and Territories; to ensure that agricultural and veterinary chemicals are effective in respect of the use for which they are cleared; and, lastly, the Bill seeks to ensure that evaluation of chemical products is carried out in a timely and efficient manner.

But when one looks at the objectives of the Democrats' motion, it will be found that they are poles apart from those of the Bill. They are not only poles apart; they are vin- dictive. I will also briefly summarise point by point what the objectives of the proposed Committee are as set out in the notice of motion given by the Democrats:
(a) the adequacy of arrangements under the legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and coordination system for agricultural and veterinary chemicals;

I can assure you, Mr President, that with the speedy passage of the main Bill itself, there is no need to carry out an immediate inquiry. That inquiry will not be so immediate either because it is stated in the terms of reference that a final report be brought out by the last sitting day of 1989 which is a long way down the track. It is also stated that a report is required by the first sitting day of 1989, which means, on that score, that the Select Committee would not have been in action.

There has been a big inquiry by the Australian Agricultural Council on the need for such legislation. That has been done and has certainly been reflected in the legislation in front of honourable senators at present.

I turn to the second of the Democrats' objectives, which is the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems. This is exactly where we see the ideology of the Australian Democrats coming through in their notice of motion. The other night I called this a witch-hunt. Having read their objectives properly and seeing some of their intended amendments to the Bill, I am more strongly convinced that this is nothing but a witch-hunt when compared with the solid basis of the legislation at hand. I spoke to one of the Australian Democrats last week about a special type of wheat which they want Australian wheat growers to produce without using any chemicals. That might be viable if one could get about $800 per tonne for it. Once again their ideology comes through on that point.

The Democrats' last point is the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives. That is nothing but a doubling up because, as I informed the Senate the other night, the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) is about to lodge the report of its inquiry into this matter. That report is due by the end of the year and, as I said previously, it will be the result of experts looking properly and objectively into the problems that may or may not arise from the need for and the use of these chemicals in Australia. That report is being put together by Australia's most eminent agricultural scientists and there is no way in the world that we need another wide-ranging inquiry before we see the results of that one.

Had the ASTEC report been with us and in the unlikely event that it had not addressed the problem or the issue, I could have excused this call for another inquiry. But we are attempting here to set up another inquiry immediately without waiting for ASTEC's findings. On the other hand, the legislation before us is very definite and it could be made operative as soon as it passes through the Parliament.

The other evening and again this morning I described the Democrats' proposal as `a vindictive witch-hunt' compared with the legislation's intentions. I will give just one example of how I think it is a vindictive witch-hunt. I just happened to cast my eyes over the Democrats' proposed amendments to the Bill. Had they had any nous, they would have left them, together with their proposal for an inquiry, in their hidden agenda. The Democrats have told us that they intend to move certain amendments to clause 20 of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill. The Bill proposes a penalty of $2,000 or imprisonment for 12 months, or both, for a person who releases confidential information-in other words, patent information or anything concerning a manufacturer. As I said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, for your ruling a few moments ago when I sought to take a point of order on Senator Panizza. SPEECH.PARA: That is relevant, of course, to this very narrow matter which is before the Senate; that is, whether these two matters-namely, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 and the motion which Senator Powell has proposed for a wide-ranging inquiry-should be dealt with cognately. We are indeed dealing with a very serious problem: the registration and regulation of agricultural chemicals and pesticides which can cause and have caused very significant damage to the environment, to the health of farmers and to our agricultural export industry. They are very important matters.

On the one hand, the Bill deals with the mechanisms by which agricultural and other chemicals should be registered and regulated; namely, by the creation of a Federal authority to replace the State authorities-a proposal with which we totally agree. On the other hand, the motion deals with the adequacy of those mechanisms.

I will deal now with the importance of investigating the adequacy of those mechanisms to show how important that element is in relation to the operation of the foreshadowed body. I will deal with the way in which the new body will be totally dependent upon information which will come from the chemical industry. It is information on which that new body will decide to register a chemical or not, modify its terms of application and the conditions it will lay down for the use of that chemical. Let us look at a couple of examples. We have extensive literature that shows that chemical companies in the past have suppressed, filtered, distorted and invented information which has been given to the bodies not only in Australia but also in other parts of the world. On the basis of that information government authorities have registered chemicals and those chemicals have come into widespread use and have had a very significant impact on people's health.

Take the example of dibromochloropropane (DBCP). In 1960 it was developed by the Dow Chemical company in the United States. Dow obtained evidence in its experimental work that DBCP caused sterility in male rats. DBCP got onto the market because that information was not revealed to the Environmental Protection Agency and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the United States, which have the responsibility for registering such chemicals. The procedure in the United States is precisely the same as the procedure which has obtained in Australia up to the moment. That procedure will also obtain under the new legislation, because the new legislation does not envisage the establishment of laboratories or alternative sources of information for the registering authority.

DBCP was supplied to a number of formulators. It was supplied to the Occidental Chemical Corporation in California. In 1974, 14 years later, a group of workers sitting around and comparing notes in the lunch room at the Occidental Chemical factory suddenly realised that none of the men working in that factory had had any children for quite some time. Investigations then revealed that all those men were sterile. It took from 1974 to 1976 for DBCP to be withdrawn from the American market, and it took until 1979 for recommendations that DBCP, which had come into widespread use in Australia, particularly in vineyards, be withdrawn to be put through the individual State bodies in Australia. That was almost 20 years after Dow obtained information which indicated that DBCP caused sterility in male rats-information which was not given to the registering authorities.

The creation of the registering authority which is anticipated by the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill is not in itself a sufficient protection to prevent very hazardous chemicals getting onto the market, because at the time when attempts are being made to get new chemicals onto the market the developing companies are very often either the principal or sole source of information relating to the hazards of those chemicals.

Let us deal with an article which appeared in the journal Nature. When I mentioned Nature on one previous occasion, some members of the Opposition joked and said, `Is that something to do with skin flick photographs?'. I remind members of the Opposition who do not know what Nature is that it is probably the second most widely read science journal in the world. It was found that information provided to the United States FDA in relation to a drug had been very highly filtered. The journal states:

FDA regulation drugs and food additives is based largely on safety data submitted by the manufacturer of proposed new products. Thus, if manufacturer's test reports are unreliable, for any reason, much of the basis for FDA's regulatory actions could be open to doubt.
Exactly the same applies to the new body now proposed in the agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation. The article continues:

. . . animal tests, it should be noted, are particularly important since they provide the chief means of identifying whether or not new products may have potential long-term problems such as carcinogenicity, teratogenicity, and mutagenicity problems which don't show up in clinical trials on humans.

I point out that teratogenicity and mutagenicity do not show up until later generations, and carcinogenistic problems do not show up for 15, 20 or 30 years. It is very important that we properly get information to the body which is now being set up so that that body will make a proper assessment. The article in Nature-the report of an FDA Commissioner, Mr Alexander Schmidt, in relation to a specific substance that was put before the FDA in the United States-goes on:

The deficiencies . . . were uncovered during inspections of `major pharmaceutical firms, inspections of several private contract testing facilities, and internal reviews of toxicity studies of color additives conducted by FDA.
The problems included the following:
`Pathology reports submitted to the agency were inconsistent with the original autopsy records',
Microscopic tissue slides were conducted by more than one pathologist, each of whom came to different conclusions yet only the conclusions favourable to the drug were submitted to the agency',

No records were kept for any individual animal in one long-term feeding study, `despite the fact that the records were required for proper analysis of the study and were represented to the agency to exist'.
All these problems indicate potential defects in the structure the legislation would set up.

SPEECH.PARA: I continue in relation to the way in which chemical companies, and in this case a pharmaceutical company, have repeatedly distorted the information they have given to regulatory authorities, one of which is exactly comparable to the one this legislation intends to set up, in such a way that dangerous chemicals, including dangerous drugs, have got onto the market and posed a significant hazard. In one toxicity study gross changes of tissue began to appear yet management was not made aware of these alarming changes for approximately four to eight months. In a study done by an independent testing laboratory the Food and Drug Administration was told that animal tissue samples had been examined, when a review of laboratory records indicated that the tissue samples had never been collected. I can only suppose that those members of the Opposition who have spoken are not really concerned about farmers; they are really concerned about the welfare of the chemical industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my objection to the devious practice which is sought to be foisted upon us by a conspiracy between the Australian Democrats and the Government to cognately debate the virtues of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 and the notice of motion given by the Democrats to establish a Senate select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. SPEECH.PARA: This proposed committee has absolutely no virtue whatsoever and the Democrats know it.
