The Democrats have not one jot of interest in or consideration for what the private sector groups think in this issue.

If they were really concerned about the issue, they would probably listen to organisations such as the National Farmers Federation. They would probably listen to organisations such as the Cattle Council of Australia, the Wool Council of Australia, the Australian Horticultural Growers Council and the Australian Council of Egg Producers. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia, they would not listen to. However, one would think they might also listen to the Confederation of Australian Industry. Therefore out of those seven organisations which are opposed to this ratbag idea, there is only one that one would think, with commonsense, they would not listen to because they do not like the chemical companies. One would think that they would probably listen to the other seven, but no, they do not. Their attitude is, `Let's just shoot the farmers in the foot again'.

As I was saying the other day, Mr Deputy President, I am very concerned about the fact that the Government has been dragging the chain on this legislation. It is legislation that is needed and the damage that has occurred to the primary producers is largely because the chemicals that were used in Australian agriculture years after they were banned in agriculture in the United States were not considered by this Government to be undesirable. The organochlorins that were banned in the United States in the 1970s--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or by Liberal-National governments.

—Isn't it just amazing! We have Senator Powell carrying on here as though she has I do not know what wrong. Unfortunately for us, I think she is next on the list of speakers but she does not seem to be able to control her tongue at the moment. Nevertheless, I will try to carry on while she is rabbiting on.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that my time is running out so I will conclude by saying that we must look at the problems of the farmers. As I have said, there are still more than 1,000 farms quarantined. These farmers have every reason to complain that the assistance they have received from the Federal Government is totally inadequate. The Liberal Party of Australia actually recommended a committee of inquiry that would look at compensation, but the Government would not come at that committee. That is how we have ended up with another stupid committee to assess:

. . . the adequacy of arrangements under the legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and co-ordination systems for agricultural and veterinary chemicals; . . . the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems; and . . . the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.
That is what this Committee is looking at. Just imagine what will happen in relation to the last of those objectives:
the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.

The Democrats will wheel in the greenies on that point just to try to prove that the chemical companies are doing all the wrong things. Our proposal would have included the investigation of the use of such chemicals by government instrumentalities and the question of compensation and assistance to producers. Therein lies the difference. The Democrats want a witch-hunt against the chemical companies; we are trying to assist the producer. Clearly it suited the Government to divert the purpose of the committee from those matters that might embarrass it, especially in regard to assistance and compensation. It has refused to acknowledge the fact that beef producers were bearing the cost of a national problem which they did not cause. Instead the Government and the Democrats are trying to launch this inquiry which will do nothing to assist producers. In fact, our agricultural exports may actually be damaged if this inquiry provides a platform for those snake oil merchants who make wild statements about the harmful effects of chemicals which are essential to primary production and which pose no threat to health at all.
Honourable senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot hear the rabbiting on so there is no point in my responding to interjections. Probably they are inane, so I am lucky that I cannot hear them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will not look at the simple fact of life: there are chemicals which are essential to primary production and which pose no threat to health at all-none whatsoever. The Democrats will not look at that; they do not have the capacity to do so. Instead of looking at ways to assist the producers, the Democrats bring forward a proposal which could easily degenerate into a witch-hunt against the chemical industry. Yet the fact that we are debating this Bill to institute effective clearance shows that problems arise through lack of proper regulation, not the misdeeds of chemical producers.

In supporting the Bill but certainly opposing the inquiry, I foreshadow my support for our Opposition amendments which will ensure that the legislation does not create injustices or unnecessary problems for manufacturers. In particular I support the inclusion of the word `significant' in clause 22, regarding the obligation of companies to supply information to the Council. Without this qualification a company would be faced with heavy penalties for failing to report very minor and inevitable variations in testing. The Opposition is hopeful that the Government, having indicated acceptance of some of the Opposition's amendments, will maintain a very open mind to constructive alterations. I cannot finish without again further expressing my great concern at the decision that has been taken by this Senate, only a matter of minutes ago, to set up an inquiry that can only be dangerous to our exports and to our rural sector generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, be established to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the adequacy of arrangements under the legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and co-ordination systems for agricultural and veterinary chemicals;
(b) the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems;
(c) the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.

(2) That the Committee may consider and recommend amendments to the legislation introduced into the Parliament by the Government during the 1988 Budget sittings, but not so as to delay the passage of such legislation.
(3) That the Committee present a progress report on or before the first sitting day in 1989, and that it present its final report on or before the last sitting day in 1989.
(4) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate,
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(5) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(7) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(10) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(11) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(14) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy President, and, in that event:
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorized by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(15) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

I will respond to some of the debate which occurred previously on whether this committee proposal in my notice of motion and the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 ought to be cognately debated. I noted with interest Senator Crichton-Browne's comments that cognate debates are always about issues which are related. I vividly remember in my first Budget session as a senator being involved in a cognate debate of some eight or nine Bills. I had responsibility for three of them. One was on wool, one was on eggs and the other was on nursing homes. I tried very hard and with some difficulty to find out why those three Bills were cognately debated. The rest of the Bills were tariff and customs Bills. I really think that Senator Crichton-Browne needs to search his memory for some other examples. These two issues are closely related and the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 is a very welcome move by the Government and one which has the support of the Australian Democrats. For more than a decade now, contrary to Opposition claims that this legislation is before us only because of the beef crisis late last year, the issue of national--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Most of the Opposition senators said that-just check the Hansard. For more than a decade this issue of a national assessment scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals and industrial chemicals has been discussed. It has been recognised that a scheme that ensures uniform standards of registration and uniform methods of handling chemicals is necessary. I am pleased to see recent reports which indicate that the Government will introduce similar legislation relating to industrial chemicals later this year. The Democrats will support that move as well. With respect to agricultural and veterinary chemicals, the system that has operated over the past 20 years has involved State and Federal governments in cooperating on a voluntary basis to assess and clear agricultural and veterinary chemicals prior to their registration in each State under separate State legislation. I understand that at present there are more than 100 different pieces of legislation in the different States to cover a variety of aspects of chemical registration, sale and use.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats agree with the Government that legislation providing for national assessment and clearance of these chemicals will improve and streamline the administration and the regulatory framework for the clearance and registration. We are pleased that the work carried out over a number of years has resulted in this legislation and that this has been achieved by the cooperation of Federal, State and Territory governments. A national and uniform approach was also supported by the Australian Agricultural Council.

The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Council, which is established by this legislation, will be responsible for coordinating the elevation of chemicals proposed for registration in Australia and the granting of certificates of clearance for those chemicals which satisfy the assessment procedures. Membership of the Council will comprise representatives of the participating States, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian Environment Council, the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission.

The Democrats are aware of some concerns in the community that membership of the Council should expand to include other interests such as farmers, industry, consumers and environmentalists. Certainly the Democrats believe that all interested parties should have the opportunity of participating in various ways in such committees and councils. I note that in this case the legislation grants the power to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council to establish one or a number of committees to assist and facilitate its operations. I note from the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that he expects consultative committees with industry, consumer and environmental groups now operating under the Australian Agricultural Council's subcommittee system to be re-established under this Council. The Australian Democrats will encourage the establishment of such consultative committees, which will allow and enable greater input from the wider community in this process.

Some other concerns have been put to us by industry and consumers which relate to the export of chemical products and to proprietary rights. We believe that our proposed Senate select committee, which we are now cognately debating with this Bill, whose terms of reference include reviewing the adequacy of arrangements under this Bill, will provide an appropriate forum for investigating those problems and any other problems with the implementation of this legislation. Again I stress that this is one of the positive aspects of the proposed committee. As I said, the Democrats are supporting the Bill.

I would like to address some remarks specifically to the proposed select committee, notice of which has been given by me on two occasions: in December 1987 and in April of this year. In the 10 months since I first raised with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, the possibility of establishing a Senate select committee, all the indications have been that such a committee is needed now even more than we had earlier believed. It is obvious that few people have forgotten the chemical residual crisis of last year, particularly in the beef industry. Few in the community would not have seen, heard of or read of other chemical related problems concerning a variety of agricultural products. In the last two years in particular Australia's farm leaders, agriculture Ministers, consumer groups and many farmers as individuals have called on Australia to lead the world in producing clean, unpolluted and residue free produce. The former President of the National Farmers Federation, Ian McLachlan, in May of last year outlined the concern in Europe and Asia over the levels of chemicals in foodstuffs as an example of an opportunity for Australian farmers-something said by an eminent farmer representative and rural politician which seems to have been utterly ignored by members of the Opposition in this debate so far.

In October 1987, the Victorian Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Mr Evan Walker, stated that in his view Australia could become the world leader in selling clean food to international markets. He was quoted in the Sun of Thursday, 1 October 1987, as saying that there was a growing demand in Europe, Japan and the United States for uncontaminated food. He said:
With a little extra effort Australia, and Victoria, can become world leaders in supplying these kinds of commodities . . .

I believe that the Senate is about to add to the extra effort that the Hon. Evan Walker has called for, in establishing this committee, which will assist in Australia's rural industries picking up on that opportunity. Senator Haines, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, saw that opportunity for herself on a recent trip to Europe and brought it to the attention of the Senate in Question Time last week, subsequent to her return.

A recent Country Women's Association of Australia Youth of the Year, Mr Rod Knight from Coonabarabran-a farmer; a young farm leader of the future, I would suggest-said in an article published in the Land on 18 February this year that a big no-no for Australia is to follow the United States down the path of the heavy use of drugs and chemicals. Mr Knight said that, apart from the high costs and small margins involved, there was rising consumer demand for safe food free of chemical residues. He is quoted as saying:
With the alarming figures being bandied around in the United States of 20,000 cancer deaths a year being traced back to chemical residues, consumer demand and concern must be our major concern.
This young farm leader is one of the farmers who, we have been told by the Opposition, are not interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leader of what organisation?

—The Country Women's Association chose him as its youth of the year. Mind you, we have heard a few disparaging remarks from the Opposition about the Country Women's Association lately. I am sure that it will listen to Senator Panizza's interjection as well. Mr Knight also recommended the banning of growth hormones. That is another major issue. Growth hormones are being banned in Europe. That decision will impact on Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The South Australian Minister of Agriculture, Mr Kim Mayes, announced the formation of an advisory committee on agricultural chemicals in February this year, a committee which, I draw to the attention of the Senate, includes representatives from a wide range of interest groups, including farmers, environmentalists, unionists, organic farmers, chemical companies and various health advisers, including toxicologists and allergists in particular. Mr Mayes said in his press release:
When I decided that there was a need for such a committee-
this is another eminent member of the community who, it is said by the Opposition, does not believe that we need to do work in this area-
I wanted a group of people representing the wider community who would be able to look at the issue of chemicals in agriculture from a broader perspective.
That is exactly the view the Democrats have taken. He continued:

Accordingly, I looked for people skilled not only in the effects of chemicals on pests and on the quality of produce, but also on people on the soil and on the natural environment. I also believe that it is timely to look closely at alternatives to chemicals.

The wide range of issues which the Democrats have put before the Senate as needing to be investigated by the proposed committee is totally agreed with at the South Australian State level by the South Australian Minister of Agriculture in establishing his committee. Even chemical company representatives themselves have, rightly and responsibly, expressed concern. The managing director of the world's third largest chemical company, Rhone-Poulenc, as reported in March of this year, called on chemical companies to take `more responsibility and put ethics before profits and lead other companies and develop products with less environmental impact'. That is from a leading member of the chemical industry.

It is my belief that chemical companies are concerned about possible harmful effects of chemicals on individuals, the community and the environment. As I said earlier in the debate, Mr Alan Morley, the executive director of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association (AVCA), has kept me in touch with a number of initiatives the industry has taken. I have welcomed that. It includes having brought to our attention the updating of information. AVCA has taken a number of initiatives in the interim period of 10 months since we first raised this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that he supports your proposals? You keep using his name, of course. He is totally opposed to your proposal.

—It appears that there is a misunderstanding in that organisation, Mr Morley being overseas, concerning what I said in the Parliament the last time I spoke on this issue, which was on Monday. I have checked the Hansard. I have not suggested at any time that Mr Morley would support this inquiry. I have merely said that he has kept me informed. I will be sending a copy of the relevant Hansard to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association. I do now what I did then, and commend any initiative which is taken or which might be taken by any section of the chemical industry, and certainly by an organisation representing the industry on this issue. I have in the chamber with me today an information kit which I believe is an advance. As I have said, I will continue to support initiatives the industry might take. I will quote from a draft document which Mr Morley brought to me. It describes one particularly useful and advanced way of expressing the problem which has come from the chemical industry. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Before using any home, garden or pet care product, there are a number of important questions you have to ask yourself-and be able to answer.
1. Have I done everything I should and can do to keep my garden free of pests and diseases, my pets healthy and free of parasites, my yard free of weeds and my house free of vermin?

The document goes on to list a range of-dare I say it in Senator Lewis's presence?-alternatives. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association is suggesting to people that there might be alternatives. I applaud it for doing that. The committee we propose intends to provide more information about alternatives. They may be alternative practices, alternative products, alternative processes or integrated systems of some chemical use and some use of alternatives. This is being cried out for in primary industry, as it is in the community. As I said, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association has put this suggestion in its own document. I commend it for doing so, although that is not to say that I think its record is perfect, by any means. However, I do not want it to be said that I have misrepresented AVCA's case.

These responsible initiatives are welcomed, as is the tightening of government legislation and regulations, an example of which we have before us today. The Australian Democrats and many people in the community recognise that many fundamental issues relating to chemicals and the future of Australian agriculture still need to be addressed. The Democrats see the establishment of a Senate select committee as providing a forum which can address these fundamental issues at a national level. At this point it is important that I quote some extracts from a recent paper by Professor John Lovett, Professor of Agronomy at the University of New England. I have referred to Professor Lovett's comments earlier in the debate, which has been going on for some days. Professor Lovett sets out in his paper, which we received just this year, some of the issues which need attention and hopefully resolution. Professor Lovett says:
The continuing pesticide controversy provides a classic example of the modern day malaise. No-one wants to take responsibility for pesticide-related problems-
if honourable senators care to read the Hansard of the last two or three days they will find that that certainly includes the Opposition-
and everyone would like to lay the blame at someone else's door.
That is exactly what the Opposition wanted to do. He continues:

In reality, of course, neither manufacturer, adviser, contractor, farmer nor anyone else involved with the use of chemicals in plant production is exclusively responsible for the complex problems which presently exist. It could be argued that they should have been foreseen, but this does not help to solve them.
Plant protection chemicals have been widely adopted because they appeared to offer simple answers to pest-related problems.
Looking beyond the immediate symptom of the problems some observers noted the impact of the intensive pasture improvement of the 1950's and 1960's.
In relation to this intensive pasture improvement, Dr Lovett's thesis goes on:

. . . increased the length of the growing season, increased total productivity, permitted higher stocking rates and induced greater agricultural productivity . . . However, in many areas where intensification took place the ring-barking of former times had left a tree population of uniform age. These trees were ageing and ill-equipped to withstand stresses.

But greater agricultural production and increased stock imposed further stress. This stress included compaction of soil around those few remaining trees, which damaged roots and prevented the establishment of new seedlings. The insect population boomed with the exotic pasture species being introduced and drought added to all of those environmental stresses. Professor Lovett concludes in this section of his paper:

Eucalypt dieback was the net result. The true cause was not the beetles-the obvious and simple answer-it was gross disturbance to the ecology of the region as a result of agricultural activity, a complex problem which could never be corrected by the short term, simple application of insecticides.
Yesterday's release of the coalition's environment policy actually gave me some heart, even in the middle of all of this ridiculous debate, when I read in that policy:
The degradation of land also results from the inappropriate use of agricultural chemicals . . .

The coalition in its environment policy contradicts everything that has been said in this debate and supports what Professor Lovett has said. I wonder whether the coalition in government will be about as good as this Government. In other words, are we to have a policy document that says something good but a government which does not implement it? If what Opposition senators have been saying is any indication that is a distinct likelihood. I did not find much in that environment policy to commend but I certainly commend that particular phrase.

I would like to refer a little more to Professor Lovett's information especially as I have read to Opposition senators their own policy on this issue. Professor Lovett points out that, globally, agriculture has a history of about 10,000 years. Chemical agriculture has a history of barely half a century. He goes on:

Buoyant post-war economic conditions permitted the rapid development of the major chemical industry with which we are familiar. Thus, although we regard chemical plant protection as the norm, it has a relatively brief history.
World sales of pesticides will exceed $US15 billion by the year 1990 . . . This amount is somewhat greater than the gross value of all agricultural commodities produced in Australia.

Those are the statistics of the Australian Bureau of Statistics last year. When we look at the context of chemical agriculture and listen to what the Opposition has said about cranks, nuts and people who are interested in and earning a living involving themselves in non-chemical or minimum chemical agriculture we wonder what Opposition senators know about agriculture in its full historical context. Professor Lovett goes on in his very important paper-I have already offered to give copies to any Opposition senator who is genuinely interested in this issue-to talk about encouraging developments in integrated pest and weed management systems which combine various farming practices: biological control and chemicals. He states:

This is a complex response to a complex problem, with herbicide used as one part of their management scheme. Had pesticides been employed in this way over their relatively brief history, the problems with which they are presently associated may never have arisen.

I ask the Opposition to listen to what Professor Lovett has said. I have listened to him. He has sent me this material since we proposed this committee. Obviously there are other people who are thinking straight on this issue. Professor Lovett is not a nut. He is not saying, `Kill the chemical companies. We cannot live with chemicals in any way'. He is not the only person around this country of some note who is saying those things. We are saying in support of this committee that this information needs to be brought together, that farmers in this country need some support and sense of direction to be able to move down this track, instead of having to do it on an ad hoc basis, as is the case at the moment.

We all ought to be aware of the fast and ever-changing society we live in largely brought about by technology. We are also experiencing significant attitudinal changes. Certainly, as I have said before, the attitude in the area of agricultural and veterinary chemicals has been changing rapidly and recently in both urban and rural areas. This has been reflected in the rural press. In recent months it has been very hard to find a rural newspaper which has not been involved in the debate about the hazards of chemicals in each addition. The National Farmer editorial of 26 August this year, to which I referred the other day, faces up to the realities of these changing times in a way which the Opposition seems unable to do. It points out that `clean' food has become an international trade issue and will become more of an issue as this century comes to a close. It goes on:
. . . Australia is in a prime position to take advantage of it because of our remoteness from the ``dirty'' environment of the Northern Hemisphere.
But to do so, we must demonstrate how ``clean'' we are again and again. Part of that demonstration is jumping on any problem-publicly and openly-
even, dare I say it, by way of a Senate inquiry-
as soon as it appears, rather than waiting until we are told we have transgressed.
I make the assumption that the National Farmer editorialist in this case even believes we should be involved in some preventive measures.

In proposing this committee the Democrats were acutely aware of the signals coming from Europe, the United States of America and within Australia on this issue. As I said earlier, the European Community is implementing a ban on the use of hormonal growth promotents from 1989. In addition, it is undertaking reform of the common agricultural policy and the development of rural alternatives to promote farming systems which are not dependent on the use of fertilisers, chemicals and high energy inputs. In some regions in West Germany and Denmark incentives are being given to farmers to switch to organic systems. The New Zealand Government is similarly supporting, promoting and legislating for organic agriculture. Right now in the United States there is legislation before Congress which, if approved, will require all imports of raw agricultural products to be accompanied by a list of all pesticides used in production. This will impact on Australia. In addition, at local and State level in the United States community pressure has resulted in `right to know' clauses being included in all kinds of legislation. In relation to chemicals, such legislation recognises the rights of workers, consumers, farmers and residents to know the contents of the food they consume or work with and the regulations for neighbourhood spraying.

The Democrats recognise that chemical fertilisers and pesticides have played a significant role in increasing food production in the past 40 years. At the same time we recognise that their use has increased 32-fold in the last 35 years, bringing with it documented evidence of lower productivity as soil quality declines, which is recognised in the coalition's environment policy; water pollution; danger to other species; and harmful effects to human health through long term exposure to chemical residues in food, water and air. In addition, the number of pesticide resistant insects and pests has increased, with many resisting even the newest chemicals on the market. These issues are profoundly important for Australia's domestic and international economy.

An issue about which great concern has been expressed in words in the Senate recently-particularly on the Opposition side, and very much so in the case of the Democrats-is the reduction in funding for research generally, but particularly rural research in my case. Dare I suggest that the process of gathering this information, putting it before a Senate committee and having such a committee report to the Senate might actually improve our chances of ensuring that the Government funds the sort of research that is necessary into such issues as pesticide resistance, integrated pest management and the other issues to which I have already referred. These issues, as I said, are profoundly important for our whole nation and our whole economy-our agricultural resource base and the health of our people.
A recent report from the World Commission on Environment and Development entitled Our Common Future states:
Ecology and economy are becoming ever more interwoven-locally, regionally, nationally and globally-into a seamless net of causes and effects.

I strongly resent the suggestions made earlier by Opposition senators that the Democrats have only recently become concerned about this issue. They do not like our being concerned, and they accuse us of coming to that concern only recently. Improvements in this area were among the very first objectives of this Party when it was formed in 1977, and many of the people who have joined the Party, including my colleague Senator Coulter, have a fine history of activism, work and knowledge in this area and have an understanding of the concern expressed in the international report from the World Commission on Environment and Development. The report, in its sections on agriculture, says that there is no doubt that nations must `promote ecologically sound farming practices' in order to ensure sustainable agriculture for the people of the world.

In Australia increasing numbers of farmers want to learn about more ecologically alert farming practices, perhaps the most spectacular example being the recent field day held in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's home State of Queensland by Graham and Sandra McNally, when 1,300 people came to see the farming practices that those people use. But individual farmers and organisations cannot and should not be expected any longer to undertake the information sharing and promotional processes involved. Dr Kate Short from the Total Environment Centre said recently:

A decrease in the use of pesticides is a question of transition. They do play a role in agriculture at this time. However, we are also in the position of being able to look at the alternatives. The problem has been that the people who have had this expertise do not have the resources and monetary backing to communicate these methods and ideas to others.

They certainly have a struggle communicating them to the Opposition. Governments have a responsibility to the Australian people to play their part in ensuring and promoting purity in our agricultural products; maintaining and expanding our markets; and ensuring the health of our community, our agricultural resource base and our environment.

The Democrats believe that Australia must take stock of where chemical dependence could lead us and of the alternative options that are open to us; hence our move to establish a Senate select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals, the terms of reference of which emphasise future directions and strategies so that as a nation we can address the problems and challenges for agriculture with foresight and in a responsible way. My colleague Senator Coulter will make some further remarks. We will be moving amendments in committee simply on the question of penalties. I commend the Bill, as an enlightened piece of legislation, and the establishment of such a committee, to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity of participating in the debate on the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988. In doing so, I state that the Opposition generally supports this legislation. However, we are debating cognately with this Bill General Business notice of motion No. 70 brought forward by Senator Powell on behalf of the Australian Democrats-aided and abetted by the Government-to establish a Senate committee of inquiry to investigate the wide-ranging use of farm chemicals in Australia. The Liberal and National parties are opposed to the establishment of the committee proposed by Senator Powell, as was obvious from the vote in the Senate earlier today. I believe that the establishment of such a committee is an entirely different matter from the Bill that we are debating. The committee proposed by Senator Powell would give people the opportunity to come before it and allege that chemicals being used by primary producers in Australia are poisoning our food and primary produce. This would be to the detriment of the sale of our primary produce on world markets-but, then, I do not think the Labor Government or the Democrats worry too much about that.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt there are some in the community who question the use of chemicals in food production, but most people would agree with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Kerin, that the controlled use of chemicals in food production has been justified. The Senate must realise that the Democrats' proposal would duplicate the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) study of chemical residues in agricultural products, the draft report on which is expected in early December. The Democrats' proposal for a committee of inquiry would also duplicate the work undertaken by task groups formed by the Australian Agricultural Council. I believe that, because of these duplications, the costs of the proposed inquiry cannot be justified.

There is no doubt that the Democrats' proposal reveals their prejudices and obsessions about chemical companies. Senator Powell's motion does not recognise the need for a speedy resolution of the problems of compensation and assistance for quarantined farmers. The National and Liberal parties were aware of the effect of the residue problems on the rural sector and, particularly in Western Australia, have moved to have something done. I believe that the inquiry proposed by the Democrats could develop into a witch-hunt aimed at Australia's 55 chemical manufacturers. In my opinion it is stupid even to consider moving for a Senate inquiry, as proposed by the Democrats and supported by the Government, when the ASTEC study of chemical residues in agricultural products is not complete and the report on which, as I said earlier, is not due until early December.

Let me deal with the Bill before the Senate. It should be noted that the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry and the widespread and safe use of chemicals, particularly in the advanced agricultural economies of the world-Australia being one-have transformed agricultural production. The productivity of farmers and the ability to store food products safely have been transformed. Without these tremendous developments in chemicals, the world would now be starving-regrettably, there are many starving people in the world-and even here in Australia we would not have the ability to sustain our large and growing population. Australia would be a far poorer country without the widespread use by farmers of these chemicals, thus enabling us to feed ourselves and to export desperately needed products so that we may maintain our standard of living.

In spite of all the incentives and advantages given by government to the manufacturing and other non-primary industries of this country, agriculture today provides a net 50 per cent of our total exports, produced by about 5 per cent of our population. I believe that that is a tremendous achievement. Those who criticise the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals are often themselves beneficiaries. They enjoy the standard of living that we all enjoy but have the hypocrisy to criticise the use of those very chemicals. Chemical companies, farmers and State departments of agriculture in Australia have a very good record in the use of these chemicals. I was interested to read in the Australian last week a report of comments by Mr Alan Morley, Executive Director of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association. The article stated:
He urged pesticide regulators to adopt a higher profile to reassure consumers that present laws and regulations on chemicals were sufficient.
It was important the public received reassurance from an independent `referee'.
`It is not enough that consumers are being protected. They must be told and reassured,' he said.

In the 1950s my husband, through our aerial spraying company, did a lot of work in western Queensland spraying brigalow. The fact that brigalow was killed by such spraying enabled vast areas of western and central Queensland to be developed and grassed and naturally gave the opportunity for graziers to run many more sheep and cattle on such country. It is obvious to me that agricultural chemicals have played a part in development and production in Australia. Even at present on our property at Kingaroy we are growing kiwifruit and avocadoes, all of which have to be sprayed with chemicals to stop fruit-fly. Of course the same spraying has to be carried out wherever fruit is grown. I think of the apples and grapes in the Granite Belt in Queensland, of all the fruit in the orchards of New South Wales and of Victoria, which you represent, Madam Acting Deputy President, as well as in Tasmania and South Australia-indeed, wherever there are orchards throughout Australia.

However not only is the consumer, by consumer choice, largely protected from any sort of hazard by the use of modern chemicals, but also there has been a real effort to ensure that the chemicals applied to crops are applied in a form and at a concentration that will not put the ultimate consumer at risk. As a nation we are dependent on the use of farm chemicals. Indeed, a good deal of the food produced across the globe disappears because it is consumed by some form of pest or disease. There is no doubt that we will have an increasing dependence on chemicals if we are to continue to help a hungry world. There is no doubt that chemicals rank with mechanisation in providing us with the opportunity to increase our agricultural production. It is interesting to note that 100 years ago one farmer produced enough food to feed six people. Today, that farmer produces enough food for 70 people.

I point out in addition that there has been a dramatic increase in the amount of land available for tillage thanks largely to chemicals. We often think of pesticides as being the only chemicals used to get our fruit, vegetables and grain crops to us in a consumable form, but we forget that weedicide use has been one of the major inputs required to increase agricultural production. These weedicides, rather than being chemicals that we ought to fear or that people say are in some way destroying our environment, have been a key in allowing us to secure much of the environment that machinery would formerly have destroyed. However, we do have to remember that aggressive use of agricultural land does have its problems. Landholders must be aware of them and balance the use of chemicals and their safe containment against the benefits of increased and cheaper production of food and, indeed, clothing. Another problem that must be recognised is the runoff of agricultural chemicals into streams and oceans, and also the problem of the rising watertable and hence salinity. However, rural people are responsible people who want to do the right thing by the environment, by the land and by the population at large.

The legislation before the Senate proposes the establishment of an Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council which will enhance the uniformity of agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation across the States. It is to be hoped that the legislation will ensure that those chemicals work well, while lessening the hazard they might pose to the environment, and allow us to reassure those who buy our products on the export market that what we are providing to them is the sort of foodstuff that they can consume safely. It is proposed that chemicals currently in use in Australia should be regarded by the proposed council as cleared for use, while new products will be evaluated to ensure that they can be used safely.

The legislation before the Senate will allow exporters and consumers to be assured that the chemicals applied to the fruit and vegetables they sell or eat will not put anyone at risk. However, the Senate should note that the Queensland Government does not want to go ahead with the arrangements in the Bill as it stands at present. The Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, the Hon. Neville Harper, has written to Mr Kerin saying that Queensland does not like the agreement it is being asked to enter into, and has suggested an alternative agreement. As at Friday the Federal Government had not replied to Mr Harper's alternative agreement.

Before completing my remarks I do wish to mention a number of private sector groups that are opposed to the Australian Democrats proposal to set up a committee. I refer to the National Farmers Federation, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Wool Council of Australia, the Australian Horticultural Growers Council, the Australian Council of Egg Producers, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia Ltd and the Confederation of Australian Industry. I note, too, that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy himself has said he only grudgingly supports the establishment of the committee proposed by the Democrats. I do not know why the Minister did not organise Labor members and say he would not have it at all, because it is not necessary in view of the Australian Science and Technology Council study on chemical residues of agricultural products under way at present. I believe it would be much more sensible for the Senate not to waste its time setting up a committee until after the results of the ASTEC study are known, and if there are then any issues outstanding they could be looked at. I certainly support the Bill but I am still not in favour of the committee proposed by Senator Powell on behalf of the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Senate has voted to debate cognately the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and the motion to set up a Senate committee, because as I indicated earlier I believe they are closely related. I want to establish first of all my credentials for speaking on this matter. Certain statements have been made about greenies, with people asking where were they before the beef residue story broke.

SPEECH.PARA: By the early 1970s I had already been concerned for many years, through my association with the environment movement, about the use of organochlorin pesticides in Australia, particularly because of their persistence in the environment and because of their solubility in human body fat so that they tend to accumulate. In the early 1970s I carried out what to my knowledge is still the largest survey of the content of DDT in human body fat that has ever been carried out in this country. I looked at autopsy specimens from over 300 people from a wide range of occupations, estimated their DDT levels, and looked at the occupations they had had during their life, their causes of death, and the illnesses that had been associated with them. Rather interestingly, I found that there was indeed an association between higher levels of DDT in human body fat and those causes of death which came within the broad ambit of malignancy. I am not saying, and I could not say from that epidemiological study, whether DDT was causing an increased incidence of cancer in Australia. For instance, it may be that, because DDT was used on tobacco crops and because smokers have a higher incidence of cancer, so those who smoked had a higher expectation of developing cancer and also had higher levels of DDT. Nonetheless, the association was there.

One of the reasons I undertook that work was that from the 1960s I had been concerned about the use of these chemicals in Australia and had indeed been attempting for 20 years to head off the use of these very persistent chemicals on such a widespread scale. It is therefore rather distressing to hear people such as Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Brownhill criticise people like myself for not having taken action which much earlier might have headed off the whole problem with the beef industry in Australia.

As long ago as 1963 Rachel Carson wrote the book Silent Spring. As well as being an excellent author, she was a very celebrated marine biologist. She really did know what she was talking about. But nobody took any notice at that stage. To turn around, as Senator Knowles has done, and criticise the greenies for wanting to look at the subject is simply not to recognise that, if the greenies had been taken notice of 20 or more years ago-and I am proud to be called a greenie-Australia would not have a problem with the residues of very persistent chlorinated organic compounds in beef tissues.

I suppose one could also draw attention to the fact that by the late 1960s and early 1970s assays of human breast milk were showing evidence that, had it been cows milk and put on the market, it would have been banned. We had that evidence in the late 1960s and we had it well corroborated by the 1970s; yet again as a nation we took no action. It was only other countries becoming concerned about the health of their residents and taking action against our beef exports which caused Australia to take action which should have been taken and would have been taken, if those in the environment movement had been listened to, many years earlier.

I have no intention whatsoever of blaming farmers. Farmers, to a large extent, have been the meat in the sandwich in this whole unfortunate business. As I will develop later, farmers have been exposed to information about chemicals predominantly from chemical manufacturers and departments of agriculture. They have had very little information available to them from other sources which would have allowed them to take a more comprehensive view. That is one of the reasons why this Senate committee is being created-to provide other sources of information.

Here is just one example of another chemical with which I have had some association in my existence as a medical practitioner. Many years ago I was consulted by a farmer on the west coast of South Australia who had been driving his tractor on his farm, using 2,4-D as a weedicide on his wheat crop. I am not talking about DDT or other organochlorinal chemicals; I am talking about 2,4-D. He had been so overcome by this chemical that he became almost unconscious. He attempted to drive out of his farm gate with the arms on his boom spray still unfolded, with quite catastrophic consequences for both the tractor and the boom. He was not found until some hours afterwards. When he did not turn up at home his wife came out to find him slumped unconscious beside his tractor. It took him some nine months to recover from that episode. He had severe disturbances of his mental processes. He was getting headaches, insomnia, and so on, and was quite incapable of working for quite a long time. We are not in any sense wanting to blame farmers. Through the creation of this committee we are attempting to establish a system which will ensure as far as possible that farmers in the future will get independent sources of information and will not, therefore, be in a position in which their products can be banned, their farms quarantined, and their livelihoods interfered with.

One factor that convinces me of the need for this committee is that the regulatory bodies in Australia so far, that is, bodies set up under State departments of agriculture, have been extremely conservative with respect to the registration and regulation of chemicals and have more or less taken the view that chemicals are safe until proved unsafe. I will give one current example of why we need to set up this committee. The agent albendazole appeared only during the 1980s. The Australian Agricultural Council, in resolution 7 of its recent report of its 130th meeting, stated:
Council NOTED that authorisation in the United States for albendazole was withdrawn in 1985 because of concerns that it was carcinogenic.
In other words, it was capable of causing cancer. To continue:

In Australia the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) has examined the same toxicological data but does not agree that albendazole is carcinogenic. The NHMRC Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals Committee has recommended that the maximum residue limit (MRL) for sheep muscle be increased from 0.1 to 0.2 mg/kg and that the MRL for edible offal of sheep be increased from 0.1 to 3 mg/kg . . .

That is a 30-fold increase in Australia, yet in 1985 the Americans banned the use of this agent because they believed it to be cancer causing. Furthermore, it recommended that the 10-day withholding period be deleted. I refer also to the Encyclopaedia of Chemical Technology, volume 23, which states:
There has been some indication of teratogenic effects-
in other words, birth defects-
with albendazole and cambedazole.

This indicates that we still have in this country conservative attitudes in relation to the registration and regulation of chemicals and that further down the track we are very likely, if these practices are not changed, to run into further problems similar to the beef residue problem which will impact adversely on farmers and on Australia's trade and which could be avoided if we were to turn this very conservative attitude around and take what I believe to be a more responsible attitude to the use of chemicals.

I certainly am not in any sense opposed to the use of farm chemicals. The vast bulk of farm chemicals probably are quite safe, but to assume that all farm chemicals are safe and that even ones that are registered and used according to directions will not have adverse effects is simply to put one's head in the sand. But it seems to me that that is what the Opposition is doing.

The inquiry, amongst other things, is to look at the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who spoke just before me, talked about fruit-fly. There are non-chemical ways of addressing the fruit-fly problem. There are biological control mechanisms. The sterile male technique has been particularly successful and I believe was developed around the fruit-fly problem. So there are non-chemical ways of achieving the same sorts of objectives and, to the extent that they are practical and economical, they should certainly be used in preference to chemicals.
Another term of reference is:
the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.

In contemplating the use of farm chemicals we are not simply looking at the farm industry in isolation. Senator Bjelke-Petersen said that one farmer now provides food for 70 people. Of course, she happens to be wrong because a lot of the people who support that farmer by way of making the chemicals, transporting them, applying and testing them, making the farm machinery and providing the fuel for all these other things, are also a necessary part of that food production. So it is a bit simplistic to say that one farmer feeds 70 people. I believe that, directly or indirectly, some 25 per cent of the Australian population is linked with the production, the transporting, the processing and so on, and the making of food available to people.

Conventional agriculture, as practised in Australia in recent years with its broad acre farming and heavy use of chemicals and pesticides, has brought a host of problems. It is distressing to find that the Opposition is taking such a narrow, backward looking view. It is really locked into an economic, exploitative view which should have disappeared many decades ago. We should be taking the view that we have a responsibility not only to this generation but also to generations for a very long time in the future and we should be doing all that we can to preserve the productive capacity of farmland. In many instances, the farming practices that are currently in use have not achieved that. I think the Opposition agreed, when Senator Powell put up a motion recently relating to soil degradation, that there has been massive soil degradation in Australia. Part of that is related to farming practices, some of which relate to the use of chemicals and artificial fertilisers.

As a consequence of that degradation, the livelihoods of many farmers have been ruined through the contamination of their farms with pesticides. Figures have already been given in relation to the number of properties that have been quarantined. Moreover, some of the farms have been quarantined not because the farmers deliberately applied these chlorinated organic pesticides to their farms but simply because contaminated material was brought in quite unbeknown to them. For example, one South Australian farmer had his entire herd of 400 pigs shot and buried when his farm was quarantined. It was discovered that the pollution had come from 50 tonnes of feed barley bought from a farmer across the border in Victoria.

For many years the senior officer in each State and in the Commonwealth responsible for the registration and regulation of biocides-and I use the term `biocides' quite deliberately because the words `pesticide' and `herbicide' are really euphemisms; we should recognise that these are general biological toxins that we are talking about-with only one exception, came from the agricultural chemical industry. Many of them had had a very long period of employment in the agricultural chemical industry before they became the senior officer responsible for the registration and regulation of these biocides. It is not surprising, therefore, that consistently, over a long period, farmers were being given one type of information from both the chemical companies and the departments of agriculture-namely, that the way to go was to use agricultural chemicals and any suggestion from anywhere that there were alternative ways of producing food were simply rubbished. I put on the record that, in the mid 1970s to the late 1970s I addressed a large number of seminars in universities and colleges of advanced eduction all around Australia and I debated this very question with people like Jack Snelson, the head of the Commonwealth authority. On every occasion I was rubbished for suggesting that there was any problem associated with agricultural chemicals. So I certainly do not blame the farmers, who have been presented with that monolithic source of information, who have accepted that chemicals were suitable and quite safe and who simply went ahead and used those chemicals on their farms with, as we now know, in many instances quite disastrous results.

At issue here are matters not only of scientific fact but also of judgment and emphasis. As I indicated earlier, I think it is fair to say that Australia is still-I believe quite mistakenly-taking a very lenient view with respect to biocides. I have given the example of albendazole which is banned in one country but which is still available here. I will give another example in the area of household pesticides. The agent dichlorvos was shown in 1973 to cause mutations. In 1979, when on the Four Corners program I showed a product manufactured by Bayer Australia Ltd, that company issued a $10m writ against the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The writ was recognised as a stop writ; it stayed in place for 12 months. It was then quietly dropped and was never tested in court. In the meantime, Bayer continued to advertise that product vigorously on television. I believe that subsequent evidence has established that dichlorvos is a cancer-causing agent, yet that product is still widely available on the Australian market.

As I have indicated, within established government committees there is a presumption that chemicals are safe until they are proved guilty. I believe that a more rational and reasonable attitude would be to accept that there is a point when sufficient evidence has been accumulated against a chemical for the onus of proof then to pass to the chemical company to establish that that substance is safe. I believe that we still have on the Australian market a number of substances that have passed that point but which are still in quite widespread use in this country. I emphasise again that that is not a matter of scientific argument or fact; it is a matter of judgment. I simply lay down that my judgment is that the fair, intelligent and more humane way to go would be not to treat chemicals like people charged with criminal offences before the courts-innocent until proved quilty. We should not extend that right to chemicals at all. But when sufficient evidence has accumulated against chemicals and there are serious question marks over them, the onus of proof should shift and, until their safety is established, they should not continue on the market.

Farmers are justifiably bitter because their State departments of agriculture encouraged the use of pesticides for nearly 20 years after those departments should have known of the risks. I have already indicated one of the reasons why that is so. If one were to apportion blame, rather than blame the farmers I would fairly and squarely put the blame very much on the Federal department and the State departments of agriculture. One of the things that the Bill before us does is to establish a central unifying council which will look to the matter of the registration and regulation of chemicals. That is a step in the right direction, provided the attitudes which permeate that council are not as conservative as the attitudes which have permeated individual State departments of agriculture and the Federal department hitherto.

It is both disturbing and instructive that the actions that have been taken over these farm chemicals have not been taken in response to the oft repeated concerns which I have indicated earlier, which have been raised by the conservation movement-the so-called greenies; a term which the Opposition uses as a pejorative, but which I accept with pride-but have been taken in response to the economic penalties which have been exacted against our produce by foreign countries. Again I think it is worth stressing that the interest in Australia has not been about the health and welfare of Australian people. The concern has been about the damage to our industries. I would suggest that, rather than wait until Americans become concerned about the health of Americans eating Australian produce or the Japanese become concerned about the health of Japanese eating Australian produce, we should long before have been concerned about the health and welfare of Australian people eating Australian produce and taken some action. Had that occurred, there would not be any farms quarantined in Australia at all and farmers would be much better off.

I pointed out earlier that 25 years ago Rachel Carson in her book, Silent Spring, alerted the world to the environmental impact of pesticides and herbicides. Yet the agricultural producers, the industry councils and agricultural departments have been amazingly slow to test livestock and produce, to quarantine properties showing unacceptable levels of chemical residues, and reluctant to penalise farmers who circumvent bans-and there have been some farmers who circumvented bans-on the use of certain pesticides or contaminated land. There is still a serious unwillingness on the part of these departments to consider the chemical impact in its broad ecological context. Even if we were to get as far as considering the human impact, we should be taking a much broader view of that and looking at the overall ecological impact-the impact on non-target species and the general sustainability of the environment and its ability to maintain itself indefinitely in the future.

Departments of agriculture, to say the least, have been very shortsighted. Apart from the environmental and health problems caused by the excessive use of pesticides and chemicals on farms, Australia's best opportunity to win, to hold and to expand market shares is to capitalise on the clean environment image we have and to extend that image. To argue, as the Opposition has argued, that somehow the creation of a select committee which will allow all and sundry to come before it and give evidence is going to impugn the safety and the cleanliness of Australia's food supply or Australian exported foods is to argue that we should have no Senate inquiries at all in any area whatsoever in which some nut might come along and give evidence which would damage an industry. I think it is a sad reflection by the Opposition on their fellow senators to impugn that process by suggesting that those senators would not be quite capable of working out those claims which were unsubstantiated, to support those claims which are substantiated and to carry them forward by way of recommendations for changes to legislation.

I believe there is still an extensive need for changes in the legislation along the paths I have suggested. Last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, said that all State governments apart from Tasmania had allowed an unregulated use of such chemicals as dieldrin and DDT, even though they were aware 15 years ago of the environmental problems associated with them. Looking at dieldrin, I was recently-in fact, literally just before I came into this place as a senator last year-on a South Australian Government committee looking at the problem of contamination of a school with aldrin/dieldrin, where the applicator had grossly applied aldrin to the school building, which had occasioned the whole school being evacuated for one whole term while a massive clean-up was carried out, the cost of which was almost the cost of the school. The South Australian Government was at the point of considering whether it was less expensive to tear the school down and build another school than to try to clean it up.

So even though again we have the prospect in this Bill that the registration and the regulatory mechanisms will be supervised at the Commonwealth level, nonetheless some overall supervisory role for the Senate in relation to the use of these agents and their alternatives is highly desirable. The Australian Democrats agree with Mr Kerin that the unregulated handling of biocides and chemicals in this country is `an unholy mess'. The Federal Government refused to finance the $30m a year residue testing program imposed on producers after the detection of pesticides in beef shipments to the United States and Japan last year. Research funds are still directed to conventional agriculture. This month the National Farmer reported that the Federal Government's innovative agricultural marketing program had funded-wait for it-a crocodile egg incubator, a mango slicer, aroma hops and research into fish bait. After this debate had begun I noticed in the Advertiser of 8 October that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was calling for applications for research grants, stating:

High priority will be given to market-driven projects. These may include aspects market development, transport, post-harvest handling, processing, production. Projects dealing with post-farm gate issues are particularly encouraged.

So we still have the Federal Government orienting itself more towards the downstream end of the industry, rather than the input end where the methods of productivity need to be carefully scrutinised so that agriculture becomes a sustainable activity in the long term which does not cause serious and irreparable damage to the environment.
