But it is difficult for me to answer the question whether or not I agree with Greg Harrison because he was commenting on a misrepresentation of what I said on television on Sunday. I will just explain the nature of that misrepresentation to honourable senators. I said that there had been some very extravagant figures quoted in terms of tax cuts and that Australia could not afford those extravagant figures. Within half an hour that question and answer was changed to `Australia cannot afford tax cuts'.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to answer Senator Lewis's question. One day Senator Chaney will be over here as a very old man because he will not be able to get a job anywhere else. We happen to believe in the democratic process in this country, so probably in about the year 2010 Methuselah Chaney will be over here in his wheelchair because he was unable to get a job anywhere else. That is a possibility which I can see. When he is in that situation he can answer the questions, or he can answer them in public forums now. I am answering Senator Lewis's question, which relates to a hypothetical situation upon which Mr Harrison was commenting. I do not wish to take that answer any further because I am quite happy to discuss the matter with Mr Harrison at any time and to provide Senator Lewis with the figures, as I said I would in the earlier part of my answer.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen a report on the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald that a major Sydney property developer had helped arrange the provision of cars, through the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party of Australia, to a member of Mr Greiner's staff and two political appointees in key senior Public Service positions-the head of the Cabinet Office and the head of the Department of State Development? The report also claims that a car company provided a vehicle to another member of Mr Greiner's staff. Will those vehicles be assessable either for income tax in the hands of the recipients or for fringe benefits tax through the organisations providing the vehicles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report reveals that the arrangements in relation to the provision of the vehicles were, to say the least, ambiguous, and that will make it difficult to determine the tax liability, if any. A major part of that ambiguity, of course, relates to attempts to cover up what actually happened-for example, by the Liberal Party belatedly paying for the vehicles despite the protestations of its State director and the even more belated attempt by the recipients to return the vehicles when they realised they had been caught. It is indeed a curious arrangement that vehicles now apparently owned by the Liberal Party were in the first instance registered in the names of the recipients.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister was specifically asked who would pay the tax in relation to these vehicles. At this stage the Minister is rambling on about ownership-the transfer and change of ownership. He has not, in any way, started to address the question. We are aware that this question is phrased in this way to enable the Minister to get up and make a statement, but I ask you to listen very carefully to what the Minister is saying to ensure that he restricts himself to answering that part of the question which relates to his portfolio and does not take the opportunity to take some general swipe at something about which he clearly knows no more than what he has read in the newspapers.

—There is no point of order. I listened to the question. I have no power to direct the Minister as to how he should answer it, but he must stick to the areas of Commonwealth responsibility within his portfolio.

—Mr President, that is precisely what I am doing. I am explaining why it is difficult to determine where, if anywhere, the tax liability resides for the reasons that I have already given and for other reasons which I am about to give. The key question in tax liability is in determining the relationship between the providers of the vehicles and the recipients. The key component of that is whether the recipients of the fringe benefit, in this case a vehicle, are employees of the person or organisation which provided the vehicles. If the recipients were not employees but had received the vehicles as payment for some service which had been rendered or was to be rendered, then the value of those vehicles would be assessable in the hands of the recipients for income test purposes. Another possibility is that provision of the vehicles may have been in the nature of a gratuity, in which case it would probably not be assessable for tax purposes, nor would it be deductable from the taxable income of the provider, assuming the provider had a taxable income.

ANSWER.PARA: All those possibilities would admit a relationship which was quite likely to involve a conflict of interest with public duty between those who originally paid for the vehicles and the recipients. I do not envy the Australian Taxation Office in having to get to the bottom of this complicated issue in order to determine the tax liability. However, I imagine it might get some assistance from the Greiner Government's Independent Commission Against Corruption.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I note that, in the Cabinet decision on the Helsham inquiry, Cabinet put two conditions on granting a woodchip licence to Huon Forest Products Pty Ltd (HFP)-first, that there should be sufficient wood resources available; and, secondly, that there should be consultations with local residents. Will the Minister make public the resource data and information which the Tasmanian Forestry Commission and the Minister's department will use to assess whether there are sufficient wood resources in southern Tasmania to allow the issuing of a woodchip export licence for Huon Forest Products? Secondly, will he make that information public in sufficient time to allow local residents, the wider public and Cabinet to come to an informed decision? Thirdly, will the Federal Government refuse infrastructure support for the Wesley Vale pulp mill unless the Tasmanian Government meets the Federal Government's standards on public input and allows appeals to be made against environmental conditions set for the Wesley Vale mill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I should say that the opening comment by Senator Sanders that the Cabinet decision on the Helsham inquiry put two conditions on the woodchip licence to Huon Forest Products is not true. I sought to impose those conditions to enable a logical framework to be developed for resolving a complex and difficult issue. I thought it entirely proper that those conditions be stated and known publicly as conditions of approach by me to a consideration of the issuance of a licence for export of woodchips by Huon Forest Products. Senator Sanders is right when he says that the two conditions were that there be a demonstrated resource and, because of concerns expressed by some citizens in the Huon Valley, that there be consultations for a point of view to be put by Tasmanians on the matter of the export licence. There is a third condition-and it is one in which Senator Richardson has an interest-that any such development should meet environmental standards.

ANSWER.PARA: The first part of Senator Sanders's question concerned the information there might be about the resource. The Tasmanian Government has notified the Commonwealth of the available resource for the development of Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd (APM) and Huon Forest Products in the south-west of Tasmania. Because of complications with that advice, a four-sided meeting between the State, the Commonwealth, Huon Forest Products and APM will be held on Friday in Tasmania in order to get an agreement on the database for the availability of the resource. We will evaluate the particular claims of Huon Forest Products and APM and in light of that we will make a decision about resource implications. After that meeting, I will be in a position to say whether it is appropriate for me to release those figures.

The second part of the question was whether the information would be released in sufficient time. I have already partly answered that. Senator Sanders asked whether I would inform the Cabinet of the information, the implication being that I do not keep the Cabinet abreast of this type of information. Of course, it is my obligation as the Minister for Resources to make a decision on an export licence, but naturally I always consult my colleagues where necessary, and that includes those in Cabinet, if and when necessary.

In relation to the third part of the honourable senator's question about the APM, the Wesley Vale pulp mill, the first thing that should be said is that Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, should be congratulated for bringing about, after a long and difficult period of protracted negotiations, an environment in which APM could announce the go-ahead of the Wesley Vale mill. Some 2,400 jobs will be created in the construction phase, 700 jobs directly and indirectly will be created in the operational phase and $300m will be added to our balance of payments, as about 90 per cent of the product of the mill will be exported. That is consistent with our value added approach.

Perhaps the third part of the honourable senator's question is best directed to Senator Button, who is the Minister responsible for infrastructure in relation to this development, or Senator Richardson, who is more concerned about the environmental conditions to be applied. All I can say in relation to it is that the Tasmanian Government, in this morning's Launceston Examiner, said that it will err on the side of toughness when it comes to making an environmental evaluation and no doubt we will be keeping an eye on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has stated that he will have a meeting on Friday with the State, the Commonwealth, APM and the HFP. When does he anticipate that the licence will be granted?

—That question implies that the licence will be granted. I do not know whether the licence will be granted. What I have said is that I am concentrating on developing a logical, rational framework for resolving what are complex and difficult issues about the environment, the availability of the resource and the sensitivities of the residents of the Huon Valley. In all matters of development and environment it is absolutely essential that we have a logical framework in which to work through and resolve what might be difficulties. The meeting on Friday will be one step along the road. If there can be a resolution of the resource implications for APM and Huon Forest Products, after that meeting on Friday I will have the ability to move to the next stage and, eventually, to announce what the outcome of the licence application is.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MUTUAL ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANCE IN TAX MATTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It relates to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development-Council of Europe Convention on Mutual Administrative Assistance in Tax Matters. A number of ill-informed and misleading statements have been made over the last few days relating to the potential effect--
—Ha, ha, ha!

—I just had to slip that in, Senator Stone. As I said, a number of ill-informed and misleading statements have been made over the last few days relating to the potential effect of this Convention on Australia, should Australia become a signatory to the Convention. Could the Minister advise the Senate of what action the Federal Government intends to take in respect of this Convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claims to which Senator Collins referred are completely unfounded. They have been hawked around by an Opposition which, bereft of any policy of its own, has been reduced to peddling a variety of conspiracy theories. Aside from the misrepresentations to which I have referred, the Government has reached the view that Australia is unlikely to gain significantly by becoming a signatory to the Convention. Those who were fortunate enough to be at the evening session of Estimates Committee C last night-as distinct from those who were unfortunate enough to be at the afternoon session, although they were mostly the same people-would know that the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, told the Estimates Committee that he had advised the Treasurer along those lines.
—When was that?

—I do not think the date of advice was given. As I recall, it was not given at the Estimates Committee hearing. But Mr Boucher stated that he had so advised the Treasurer. Having received that recommendation from the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasurer announced yesterday afternoon that Australia would not become a signatory to the Convention. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the press statement.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
STATEMENT BY THE TREASURER, THE HON. P. J. KEATING MP
OECD Convention on Mutual Administrative Assistance in Tax Matters
The Government has decided not to become a signatory to the OECD/Council of Europe Convention on mutual administrative assistance in tax matters.

There have been a number of inaccurate claims recently that the Convention would lead to access by various countries to confidential tax file information through a central data bank. Those claims are in fact unfounded, and of course, the Government would not for a moment countenance such a possibility.
However, apart from those misrepresentations, the Government has reached the view that Australia is unlikely to gain significantly by becoming a signatory to the Convention.
This decision is consistent with the recommendation of the Australian Taxation Office.
CANBERRA
18 October 1988

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Minister stand by the view he expressed on Sunday, before he was gagged by the Prime Minister, regarding the promised tax cuts? I quote his typically lucid remarks:

QUESTION.PARA: I mean, you know, we are really not in a position where we can indulge ourselves too much at the present time.
Can the Minister now say what are the main reasons why Australia cannot indulge itself with tax cuts next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have difficulty answering a question which is based on quite deliberate misrepresentation-and that is what the honourable senator's question is. It relates to two totally different and separate remarks. The last part of the honourable senator's question, which puzzled Senator Chaney, was, `Will you tell us why we cannot indulge ourselves with tax cuts next year?'. That has never been said by me in any forum. In fact, I have said many things to the contrary. So the honourable senator's question, as usual, starts with the misrepresentation of the sort that Patrick Partners was guilty of in his last career.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney is providing a bit of amateur coaching for me in answering this question. With the greatest respect, I do not need it. Perhaps Senator Baume has not been listening, but I have said on numerous occasions in this chamber this week that the quantum of tax cuts will be considered by the Government next year in the light of a number of parameters which have been set out. That remains the position. There is no change from what I said 20 minutes ago.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the question of indulgence by the Australian economy as a whole is concerned, let me say, as I have said over five years in this place, that the Australian economy is going through a difficult period of structural change. We still have a substantial trade deficit, which is a matter of considerable concern. In respect of those issues we cannot be an indulgent society. I do not change my view about that at all. But to attempt to relate it to the issue of tax cuts, in the way in which Senator Baume did in his question is, to say the least, reprehensible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of the recent decline in media interest in political developments in Burma, can the Minister advise the Senate what is the current situation with regard to the campaign for a transition to democracy in Burma? What prospects, if any, are there for free and fair elections in that country under the current regime? Has Australia been asked to supply observers at any proposed election? What is, or would be, the Australian Government's response to any such request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The political situation in Burma at the moment is that the military regime in Burma remains officially committed to holding free multiparty elections in Burma, the electoral commission is continuing to work and political parties continue to be formed and to register with the commission. However, no date has been set for the holding of elections. General Saw Maung, moreover, has set the restoration of law and order and the restoration of Burma's food, fuel and transport problems as preconditions for the holding of the elections. It is simply not clear when, if at all, the regime is going to regard those preconditions as having been satisfied. The Australian Government continues to urge the Burmese authorities to accede to the legitimate aspirations of the Burmese people for democracy and to move quickly toward free and fair elections.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the honourable senator's last point, Australia has received no request to send observers. If we did receive a request to send observers to what was manifestly intended to be a genuinely free election, we would certainly consider that request very seriously indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Now that we have had another bad monthly current account figure, for September, with a deficit of $990m-call it $1 billion-and bearing in mind the Minister's comments 10 days ago that we should at least wait for that figure to be released, is the Government now closer to having to `do something further on the outlays side of the Budget', as the Minister suggested was inevitable `if the current account deficit continued to run at much higher levels than had been anticipated'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I should say is that of course I reject Senator Stone's judgment about the September current account figure. Indeed, to apply what I regard as quite significant evidence to that, I might comment that I was discussing with a journalist this morning what the current account figure might be. I said, `Frankly, I don't have the faintest idea and I don't believe anybody else outside the ABS does, although a few people are quite willing to hold their hands out with advice, based on pretty specious evidence, about what it might be'. I said to the journalist that in my view any figure below $1 billion would be good news. That is what I said before I knew what it was. Admittedly, it has scraped in at below $1 billion. Honourable senators should bear in mind the point I made in the television interview to which Senator Stone has referred: there is a seasonal factor in Australia's balance of payments, with exports tending to be lower in the first half of the financial year than they are in the second half.

ANSWER.PARA: The question, I suggest, is irrelevant because it is based on a false premise. I want to make a couple of other observations about it. The first is that Senator Stone and some other people would have made massive changes to policy last October based on assumptions of economic horrors because of the share market crash at that time. He was advised by me and a number of other people in the Government to wait and look at what happened before there were any panic responses, before launching the lifeboats even though the ship was still in the harbour. He was likewise advised after the first two admittedly somewhat worrying balance of payment figures for the first two months of this financial year. The September figure is very much better and quite consistent with the Budget forecast. I repeat the warning that I gave before: it would be premature on the basis of even three months figures, let alone one or two months, to make any firm judgment about the final outcome at the end of the year.

In Senator Stone's comments about outlays, he of course inadequately quoted what I said. I explicitly said that I did not believe this would happen but that if there was a continuing run of very bad monthly balance of payments figures which precipitated a run on the dollar then probably some response on the outlays side of the Budget would be necessary. That, however, would pale into insignificance if compared with the response on the outlays side, consistent with a responsible fiscal policy, which would be required if the $20 billion men, Messrs Peacock and Howard, were actually to proceed with their irresponsible proposals for tax cuts of $56 a week for people on average earnings and pro rated above and below. This would take away $25.5 billion of government revenue, wiping out the surplus and leaving an even bigger deficit than Mr Howard left behind him in 1982-83.

Even as a proportion of gross domestic product it would be a great deal higher than the prospective $10 billion that Mr Howard left behind him in 1982. Of course, what would the chances of the Opposition be of making any adjustments on the outlays side of the Budget? The only person in the Opposition with the courage to do anything about outlays has just been sacked from the front bench.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will leave aside the latter effusions from the Minister. It may be suggested that the Minister was paying me a compliment. If so, I naturally thank the Minister, although it would be unusual, I would have to say. Am I to understand the Minister's response as implying that he, like the Prime Minister, is taking on the colouration of complacency which was reflected in the Prime Minister's remarks on this matter only yesterday evening inasmuch as he appears to regard a deficit of $1 billion or within $10m of that for September as being all right? In fact he said anything under $1 billion would be a good figure. Is the Minister really telling us that he is approaching today's figure with that degree of complacency and in doing so is he also telling us that he accepts as appropriate and as consistent with the Budget forecast of a $9.5 billion deficit for the year a deficit for the first three months, of over $3.8 billion which is more than 44 per cent of the annual figure?

—Firstly, I was not paying Senator Stone a compliment in saying that he was the only member of the Opposition with enough courage to do anything about the outlays side. If he wants to interpret it that way, that is okay. But I was actually just stating what was the bald, simple fact. I am not complacent nor, I believe, is the Prime Minister. I did say that it is too early even after three months, let alone one or two months, to make any sort of reliable or authoritative judgment about the final accuracy of the Budget estimate of the balance of payments, let alone to start changing policy every time a new monthly set of statistics comes in about any issue at all.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I draw attention to the statement made by the Minister on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation PM program last night that he had offered to pay for reunion flights for those partners of crew members of the HMS Ark Royal and HMS Fort Grange who had gone to Melbourne to see them and who missed the opportunity when the nuclear-armed warships were unable to come into port. I ask the Minister how much this exercise will cost, who will pay for it and how those claiming eligibility will be selected. I further ask the Minister whether he realises that women from Greenham Common and Women Working for a Nuclear Free and Independent Pacific held a demonstration in Portsmouth in June this year warning the flotilla of Royal Navy ships that there would be demonstrations when the ships arrived in Australia. Does he also realise that HMS Ark Royal could not dock at Valletta Harbour in Malta on the way to Australia because of opposition there to nuclear-armed warships, reflecting a rising tide of opposition around the world to nuclear port calls? Is he also aware of the latest opinion poll figures indicating that 50 per cent of Australians are opposed to nuclear-armed warships visiting our ports while only 24 per cent are in favour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of comments to make on that question. Firstly, I have had the opportunity to watch in Sydney what has happened with the visits of various warships. I have seen a number of flotillas come into Sydney and I am aware of the fact that each time there have been up to 2,000 people who have gone to the trouble of demonstrating against them. I am also aware, of course, that up to one million people have gone to view them and cheer them on. The honourable senator may quote from any survey she likes about how many people support the visits and how many do not. All I know is that the citizens of Sydney and cities all around Australia have had the opportunity to demonstrate how many people want them and how many do not on any number of occasions. Every single time the number of those people who come to view the ships and get on them as against those who demonstrate against them is thousands to one.

ANSWER.PARA: I really am sick and tired of hearing about this great movement. The reality is that the ordinary citizens of Australia, every time they are given the chance, want to get out and look at them. I did hear the Minister's statement last night. I have asked for some details of who is paying and whatever else the honourable senator asked about, and as soon as I get that information I will pass it on to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If union bans are applied in Fremantle, where the Ark Royal is now heading and where it will arrive on Sunday, will the Minister supply helicopter flights to facilitate those reunions on board the Ark Royal moored in Gage Roads? Secondly, I ask the Minister whether, in light of the public opposition to nuclear warships notwithstanding the comments that the Minister made, he and the people on the Opposition side understand that people and unions who protest are the cutting edge of the enormous amount of opposition. I ask the Minister--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. A fair degree of latitude is allowed in supplementary questions. This is not only a new question; it is also followed by a statement of principle. There is ample opportunity through other forms of the Senate for Senator Vallentine to express her views.
—I am asking a supplementary question.
—So far it has been a series of new questions.

—I do not believe that I got answers to my questions. I know that the Minister said that he would get details for me. I ask the Minister whether the Minister for Defence takes responsibility for not making it clear to the Royal Navy ships and the United States ships that nuclear-armed ships were not appropriate guests for the fleet review. Does he personally accept responsibility for the embarrassment that resulted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister totally rejects Senator Vallentine's assertion, and so do I. I do not want to go close to saying something that is unparliamentary, so I will stop there. As far as we are concerned, those ships are welcome. We have invited them in the past and we will continue to do so. I am not sure whether or not we will supply helicopter flights to the Ark Royal in Fremantle for reunions with loved ones. I do not know whether there is even going to be any problem in Fremantle. I think I explained to the Senate yesterday that the Government is holding talks with the Seamen's Union of Australia, and hopefully there will be no problem. If there is a problem, be it by ship, plane or train, love usually finds a way.

—Mr President, my question is directed to you. Are you aware that, in the course of the meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission held in Adelaide last week, a motion was adopted to the effect that papers and submissions of whatever kind shall not be presented to any parliamentary committee or any other body without the prior approval of the Commission? Are you also aware that this resolution is being relied on by the Commission to decline to provide or to delay the provision of any information to Senate Estimates Committee E and to the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs?
—That is absolute rubbish.

—It is not rubbish. I know that Senator Tate is worried about this, but it is very accurate. Mr President, are you further aware that, relying on the same resolution, the Commission is declining to provide or is delaying the provision of information to the Senate Select Committee in its investigation of a breach of the privilege of the Senate? Will you, Mr President, first, investigate this matter as a breach of the privilege of the Senate; secondly, ensure that information is not withheld, or its provision delayed, from Senate Estimates Committee E or the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs; and, thirdly, ask that the Select Committee at its next meeting thoroughly investigate the contempt being displayed by the Minister's hand-picked board of commissioners and urge the Committee to use all its powers to ensure that appropriate witnesses are available so that the Committee can properly perform the task assigned to it by the Senate?

—The answer to the first two parts of Senator Boswell's question is that I was not aware of the circumstances to which he referred. I will investigate them and report back to the Senate as a matter of urgency.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to today's reports of Israeli forces in the occupied territories having killed two Palestinian children-a five-year-old and a 14-year-old-using plastic bullets. What is the Australian Government's reaction to these events and what has it done to make its views known in the appropriate places?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is extremely concerned at those reports. The deaths are the latest manifestations of increased violence in the Israeli occupied territories. The Government has been concerned at a statement by the Israeli Defence Minister, Mr Yitzhak Rabin, last month that the Israeli Army was deliberately seeking to wound more Palestinians in a drive to crush the nine-month uprising, indicating the Israeli Government's willingness to inflict often serious injury on Palestinians in an attempt to quell violence. The Government certainly does not accept that the use of plastic bullets designed to injure rather than kill Palestinian protesters acts as a deterrent, and these latest deaths again demonstrate that these bullets can be lethal.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government does not believe that it is possible to break the spirit of the people by physical force. Our views have been made clear on numerous occasions to the Israeli Government and in international forums. The continuing violence in the occupied territories underlies the urgent need for a settlement of the Arab-Israeli dispute, based on both Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries and the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination. Only courageous political leadership on the part of both the Israelis and the Palestinians can bring this about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Following the Minister's reply to a question from his own back bench two days ago concerning the development of a new goldmine at Ballarat, I ask: Does he confirm or deny that the development of that mine at Ballarat was committed prior to the announcement of a corporate tax on gold production, and included contracts for machinery and equipment which could not be cancelled? Does the Minister agree or disagree that goldmining, especially an open cut operation, can proceed under accelerated development and be worked out in the remaining three years before the imposition of that corporate tax? Does he admit or deny that the accelerated development of goldmines and accelerated production are due to the fact that the Government intends to extend the moratorium on a corporate tax on gold production until 1 January 1991?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for his question. In terms of the Ballarat goldmining development to which Senator Panizza has referred and which was the subject of a question to me two days ago, the investment obviously was committed to that development before it was announced in the May economic statement that the goldmining companies' exemption from normal company tax would end. The significant aspect is that, in the face of that announcement, the investors continued to proceed with their investment and to the development of that mine. Indeed, as I said in answer to the earlier question, 20 new mines-some of them very significant and major mines-were announced before June of this year and in the latter half of this year some 30 new goldmines will commence operation. The fact that investors are continuing with their investment knowing that the special exemption for the goldmining industry will no longer exist indicates, in my view, that the closing off of that exemption will not have the dire consequences that some spokespeople for the mining industry suggest.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the honourable senator's question related to accelerated development. Of course, some miners can engage in accelerated development if they wish to invest further in the technology or the labour requirements that are necessary to work quicker to win a bigger body of gold. Indeed, one can see that today's prices on the world market-$US413.35 or $A510.30 for an ounce of gold-are a significant incentive. Our estimate is that it takes about $A300 to cover the operational costs of most goldmines. Their return on the world market at today's prices is $510.30 and that is a good incentive for them to continue. But they run the risk, if they try to accelerate their development, of bringing down that market price by putting more gold on the market. That is a sort of self-defeating tautology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Having taken note of the remarks the Minister made on the continuing investment in goldmining, I ask: The only barometer of the prospects for goldmining in the future being drilling, how does he explain the fact that, whereas in May of this year the drills in Kalgoorlie were working at 100 per cent efficiency, they are now down to about 15 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my answer a few days back I said that we predicted that investment in the Australian goldmining industry would peak in about 1990. We stand by that prediction. I should say that that prediction was made before the May economic statement was put down, and it remains true. Because we still cleave to that prediction as being an accurate forecast for the development track of goldmining in Australia and in view of the evidence that I have given about the number of mines to come on stream, I suggest that we cannot hold the removal of the special exemption from company tax for goldmining companies as a deterrent to further development.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator talks about the amount of exploration work being done. For most small prospectors-people who are not companies-the application of company tax will not have any effect. Might I also say that when on 1 January 1991-because I believe the legislation will pass both Houses of parliament by then-the loophole is closed off there will be 100 per cent deductability for exploration expenses as well, and that will be a deductability against the tax which will at last be paid by goldmining companies. So the incentive to maintain the exploration regime at a high level is still there and ultimately the final determinant is the prospectivity of the areas to be looked at and the price. The price is holding up very well-I gave the figures a moment ago-and the prospectivity is quite good for most parts of Australia where gold prospecting is going on at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The actions of building industry unions in Victoria, supported by the Victorian Labor Government, in victimising and harassing self-employed building trades subcontractors working on industrial and commercial building sites, for whom such work was arranged by the labour hire agency Troubleshooters Available, and the necessity for the Hawke Government to take urgent action to assist in preventing further disruption.

In September 1985, a little over three years ago, I brought before the Senate an urgency motion concerning the campaign of violence, thuggery and lawlessness then being waged by a militant, extremist, Libyan-backed union, the Federated Confectioners Association, against the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd, a small business in Melbourne. That dispute involved, amongst other things, an attempt by the union to overturn an agreement reached voluntarily between the company and its employees on terms and conditions of employment. History records that the Dollar Sweets case subsequently became one of the landmark cases in Australia's industrial relations history. Following action initiated in the courts by Dollar Sweets, in early 1988 the union made an out of court settlement of $175,000.

The debate I initiated in this place in 1985 was a key catalyst in pursuit of the Dollar Sweets case. That case proved at least three points. Firstly, it proved that the pursuit of the proper processes of the law will lead to just outcomes. As a result, the civil courts are increasingly being used to settle disputes rather than industrial muscle and intimidation. Secondly, it proved that resistance by small businesses to union strikes, black bans and other forms of coercion has strengthened and this, in turn, has had an enormous impact on the behaviour of trade unions. Thirdly, the Dollar Sweets case proved that the trade union movement is no longer seen as invincible in these areas.

The Dollar Sweets case was not unique in the industrial relations history of the late 1970s and the 1980s. Rather it was one of a small group of cases which has had a profound and beneficial effect on the pattern of industrial relations. The cases to which I refer were all ones where what seemed initially to involve almost insuperable trade union dominance proved not to be so because of the willingness of employees to stand up for their legal rights and to invoke the proper processes of the law. In this context I might also mention the live sheep export dispute of the late 1970s and early 1980s, the use of wide combs in the shearing industry, the South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute, Mudginberri, and the recent and very important decision relating to the firm Castle Bacon Pty Ltd. Most of these cases were all about the ability of employers and employees to deal directly with each other at the enterprise level. Of course, this is a central objective of the Liberal and National parties' industrial relations policy.

Time may well indicate that the dispute I bring to the attention of the Senate today will rank in importance with those I have just mentioned. This dispute concerns a small business called Troubleshooters Available which I will hereafter refer to as Troubleshooters. The foundations of Troubleshooters go back to 1973 when one of the present proprietors, Peter Bosa, set up an agency called Labourers and Carpenters Pool to supply tradesmen to the building industry. The Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) declared war on that agency and, through an intensive campaign of harassment and black bans, forced its closure in 1975. In 1976, Bosa restarted the business, this time under the name of Troubleshooters Available. In 1981 he was jointed by Brian Groves as a co-proprietor. Since 1976, Troubleshooters has been subject to a continuing series of attacks from the building unions. In more recent years, the main protagonist union has been the Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU).

Troubleshooters is part of the building industry. It is located mainly in Victoria but has an offshoot in Queensland. Its problems are confined to Victoria. It is planning to expand nationally. Troubleshooters is a labour hire agency which supplies temporary, well paid, self-employed tradesmen to contractors in the commercial and industrial sectors of the building industry. In effect, the agency organises and deploys a highly productive labour force on short term contract. Once the task or job is completed, the subcontractor may be available for other short term work, either through Troubleshooters or through his own contacts.

It is a concept with great appeal to the building industry which is subject, of course, to huge fluctuations in workloads. Troubleshooters' services are in high demand. The company has up to 300 subcontractors covering a wide variety of skills and disciplines in the field at any one time and a further 1,000 available for replacement.

Although Troubleshooters has grown during the 1980s it has, as I have said, encountered major problems from the building unions and these problems are accelerating. The company has been subjected to an extraordinary amount of harassment, intimidation and victimisation. Much of this has come directly from the building unions. The unions, though, have been supported by Victorian Trades Hall Council officials and by various Victorian Government departments and agencies. Troubleshooters has received no assistance and no protection whatsoever against these attacks either from the Victorian Labor Government or from the Hawke Government. Neither of the relevant Ministers, Mr Crabb in Victoria and Mr Willis federally, has even been prepared to meet with the proprietors.

The principle at issue in this matter is the right of individuals to subcontract their labour as self-employed small businessmen. It is also about the right of a firm such as Troubleshooters to place these subcontractors on unionised, industrial and commercial building sites. The dispute is not about whether the subcontractors should be union members. They are all members of one or other of the recognised building unions. They all have union tickets, they all have building union superannuation tickets and they all have long service leave tickets. The problem is not about whether the self-employed small business subcontractors belong to a union-they all do. Rather, the problem is about the power of the unions and their demand to determine the nature of the subcontractors' employment. It is a fundamental objective of the building industry unions to make all building workers wage earners rather than be independent and self-employed. The unions want a wage earning labour force for several reasons: it is easier to organise industrially; it is more likely to bow to the dictates of the union organisers themselves; and it is more likely to take industrial action.

Independent subcontractors, self-employed small businessmen, threaten the power of the unions to control the work force. For this reason independent subcontractors are anathema to the union movement and not only in the building industry. According to the Australian Small Business Association, subcontracting `is under attack as never before in Australia. Governments and unions seem to be acting in virtual conspiracy to squeeze subcontractors out of the economy'.

An agency such as Troubleshooters, which is able to organise and productively deploy a large number of independent subcontractors, represents a challenge to the totality of union control in the industrial and commercial building industry. Since Troubleshooters began to mature and grow in the early 1980s, it has met fierce and, in many instances, illegal opposition, firstly from the BLF and then from the BWIU. Building industry union officials declared the company to be black and threatened builders with industrial action unless subcontractors were removed from their sites. Subcontractors were threatened with permanent black bans within the industry and, as a result, business began to slide. Builders and subcontractors were reluctant to place their names on a black agency's books. Builders were quick to divest themselves against agency workers if a project was threatened.

Groves and Bosa, the proprietors of Troubleshooters, negotiated directly with the union leadership about all these matters, but after consultation with their subcontractors Troubleshooters refused to do the one thing that the building unions insisted on, and that was to alter the status of the independent self-employed subcontractors in order to turn them into wage earners. This was not in the agency's power, nor was it in the interests of the subcontractors themselves. Seeking a mutually satisfactory solution, Troubleshooters sought advice and assistance from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Victorian Trades Hall Council, the Master Builders Association of Victoria, and the then Victorian Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Crabb. None of these organisations or individuals offered any constructive assistance at all.

Troubleshooters was left with no choice other than, through the courts, to seek protection of the subcontractors' right to work. Commencing in July 1987 a series of court actions was initiated. Most of these actions have been successful. In some instances actions or investigations have been dropped. The most notable of these involved the Building Industry Long Service Leave Board. In July 1987 it mounted its fourth investigation of Troubleshooters in six years. In February 1988, on legal advice, the Board dropped all claims. There are very strong indications that these investigations over that period of six years were the result of collusion between the building industry unions and the Long Service Leave Board. High-ranking union officials are prominent members of that board. The subcontractors, whom Troubleshooters place work for, work neither for the company nor for the builders who hire them temporarily. They run their own businesses and work for themselves. The independent status of the subcontractors who work through Troubleshooters has been verified by the Australian Taxation Office and by the Victorian Payroll Tax Office.

Since Troubleshooters took the step of serving writs for protection and damages at common law, the building unions and particularly the Building Workers Industrial Union have been more reluctant to openly place black bans on building sites and risk incurring more common law damages. Instead, the unions' strategy has relied on other disguised or backdoor attacks. They have turned instead to other illegal ways of crushing the independence of subcontractors. Because legislation appears to allow union officials to close a site that they deem unsafe, it gives union organisers an industrial weapon to rid their sites of agency labour. To protect their subcontractors from trumped up claims about safety and to ensure the safety of their subcontractors, Troubleshooters itself now has 50 registered health and safety officers working through the agency. Safety on site is not the issue here. The issue, as I said, is the abuse of power by union officials.
The latest BWIU tactic is slander and lies, an example of which I now show the Senate. Honourable senators will note the swastika and the offensive words. I seek leave to table the poster.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Posters and stickers such as these have been put up around building sites in Melbourne by union officials. These same officials have asked that they not be named `or we will be in trouble'. What code of conduct motivates people such as this? Where is the courage of their convictions? They deny having anything to do with these stickers and posters, after placing them directly into the hands of various subcontractors. Such actions I believe are contemptible. In its 12 years of sustained harassment from the building unions, Troubleshooters has been unable to obtain the formal support of builders' organisations and in particular the Master Builders Association of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for that appear to be twofold. The first is that the Master Builders Association of Victoria is dominated by the major construction firms, whereas Troubleshooters' clients are small independent businessmen. The second, and related to the first reason, is that the Master Builders Association of Victoria is a signatory to the Cain Government's building industry agreement on behalf of a number of its major contractor members. The other parties to the building industry agreement are the Victorian branches of a range of building unions, the Victorian Building Trades Union, which covers such trades as bricklayers, plasterers, slaters and tilers, and the Cain Government Minister for Labour. The Victorian building industry agreement is highly restrictive. It represents a deal done by a Labor government, unions and large building contractors. It outlaws various types of subcontracting. The agreement works totally against the interests of small independent businessmen like the proprietors of Troubleshooters and the independent tradesmen whom they place in work on building sites.

TALK.START.PARA: —And totally against the interests of consumers.

—Absolutely against the interests of consumers. What it does is to attempt to destroy the capacity for self-employed contractors to work on building sites if that work is obtained through agencies like Troubleshooters.

SPEECH.PARA: The building unions have set out to destroy Troubleshooters for one simple reason, and that is that the unions see Troubleshooters' activities as a threat to their power. That is what this is all about. It is about power. It is about union power. It is about the power of the unions to control workers. It is not about whether people are members of a union. As I said, all the Troubleshooters' independent subcontractors are union members. It is not about the level of payment for work performed. The Troubleshooters' subcontractors are all highly paid. They are paid a long way above normal award provisions. I repeat: this matter is about whether building industry unions should be able to exercise restrictive, domineering, costly controls over subcontractors in the industrial and commercial building sector; whether the unions should be able to force independent small business subcontractors to lose their independence and become instead paid employees under the control of powerful trade unions.

There is a huge difference between the structure of the industrial and commercial building sector in Australia and the domestic housing industry. The housing sector is run almost entirely on a subcontract basis. As a result, the housing industry in Australia is the most efficient such industry in the world. In contrast, our industrial and commercial building sector is highly inefficient by world standards. For example, it takes some 50 per cent more man-hours, and even more cost, to build a high-rise commercial building in Australia than it does in the United States, despite the fact that in the housing sector we are more efficient than they are in the United States. The reasons for the differences in efficiency between the housing and non-housing sectors in Australia are very clear. They are the dominance in the non-housing sector of powerful unions, restrictive work practices, and the virtual exclusion of independent subcontractors. These inefficiencies in the industrial and commercial building sectors hit every consumer. Food is dearer because supermarket costs are higher. Rates and rents for office space are dearer. This gets passed on to consumers. Industrial products cost more because the factories in which the products are made cost more to build. And so it goes on right through our total cost structure.

Far from letting the unions, with the assistance of compliant Labor governments and the major building firms, further destroy the role of the subcontractor in the industrial and commercial building sectors, we should be doing all that we can to encourage and develop the role of the subcontractor. Subcontracting offers the best-perhaps the only-chance of introducing the flexible working arrangements and the efficiencies essential to control and reduce costs. The Australian dream of owning one's home is already rapidly becoming a mirage under the policies of this Government-policies which have pushed housing costs and prices and loan repayments beyond the reach of most average Australians.

If, by any chance, the union dominance, restrictive work practices and attacks on the subcontracting system that are the hallmarks of the non-housing sector were to extend to the home building sector, the results would be catastrophic. Gone forever would be the tradition of home ownership that is one of the great strengths of our nation. The prospect of this occurring is by no means impossible. Indeed, Mr Rothman, a witness for the building unions appearing before the building industry inquiry on 6 July this year, said that the housing sector should be considered as part of the building industry.

The Opposition has brought forward this urgency motion not just because one particular firm and the subcontractors for whom it arranges employment have been the victims of a long running campaign of intimidation and harassment by the building unions in Victoria. That is bad enough in itself and it is sickening that neither the Cain Government in Victoria nor the Hawke Government has lifted a finger to alleviate the situation. The Federal Minister, Mr Willis, for example, said this matter was entirely a State matter. That is not correct, of course. On the contrary, when the Opposition attempted to amend the Hawke Government's Industrial Relations Bill in ways which would, inter alia, have impacted positively on this type of practice, the Government stubbornly refused to accept those amendments.

This urgency motion is really about the right of the average Australian who wants to be independent, to remain independent, to have a job. It is about the power of the unions to prevent this. It is about whether in our so-called civilised society we stand aside and allow thuggery, intimidation and coercion to rob us of our essential rights. I urge the Senate to support this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating an urgency motion moved by Senator Short which begins with the words `The actions of building industry unions in Victoria, supported by the Victorian Labor Government' and continues on a fairly repetitious union bashing line. We in this chamber are used to debating matters of public importance and urgency motions which reflect issues which are current in the community. When we on this side of the chamber found out that this proposition was to come before the Senate this afternoon, we undertook an investigation to try to find out why it was to be put before us today. If we think back a few weeks, we recall that a series of matters of public importance came before the chamber which dealt with matters concerned with Victoria. Obviously, they were put forward as a political tactic leading to the Victorian State election, which has been and gone. In the preceding parliamentary session a series of matters came before the Senate which dealt with the constitutional referendum. Obviously they were a build-up to the referendum which was held on 3 September.

SPEECH.PARA: Our investigations today, in going through the media-the print media, in the main-to find out why a motion such as this should be moved at this time, proved to be in vain. We could find no evidence of this, other than a reference in the Age newspaper of 13 September-well over a month ago. So we are still short of evidence-and that is not meant to be a pun. We still have no knowledge as to why this matter should be raised at this point in time. Is it just a continuation of the traditional tactics of those in the Opposition to bash the trade union movement? Having heard two Opposition speakers so far, that is the conclusion one is led to. I suspect there is somewhat more to it but at this stage perhaps I should give the Opposition the benefit of the doubt and I shall wait with bated breath to hear what Senator Chaney has to say.

At the same time-I do not want to be unkind to Senator Short-perhaps he made the contribution to resurrect himself and to return to the front bench. Perhaps it was related to the two visitors in the gallery. And I recall some of the propaganda material sent to me on two occasions over the last couple of years. That probably has something to do with the company mentioned in the urgency motion before us. Maybe it is all coincidental. We shall wait and see. Hopefully what Senator Chaney has to say will indicate which is correct. We are still at somewhat of a loss.

I want to say fairly early in my contribution to this debate that the legal implications of the Troubleshooters Available case are things that I am not prepared to canvass. Our Party did talk about this matter this morning and considered whether or not we ought to raise a point of order concerning the debate, but we decided that if we did that we could end up in a debate which would last the rest of the afternoon without necessarily resolving the issue, and we do have a log jam of legislation before the chamber. So we decided it was not the best course of action to take. I will not pursue that any more.

I make one point very strongly and clearly: I think honourable senators from all States and from all parties do have some obligations-in saying this I am not casting aspersions on any honourable senator in this place or or any arguments that have taken place-in that we should not ever seek to turn this place into a court of law. If we were to do that I could pick up another legal case in which the company is involved, this one not before the Supreme Court of Victoria but before the Federal Court of Australia, and canvass arguments concerning that under the privilege of Parliament-which would be unfair to all concerned: the defendants, the plaintiffs and so forth.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to do it, nor am I and nor are any of the other speakers.

—I hope that is so; I hope that is respected. We often go close, though in saying that I am not accusing Senator Chaney at all. As I have said, I have had some correspondence from the company involved. I would call it high-powered propaganda; it is very well presented. It is almost as good as some of the material that the Australian Labor Party produces from time to time and which others seek to copy. One always copies the best. It appears, going back to my industrial relations days, that Troubleshooters Available has one hell of a lot to learn about the industrial relations system and the people who practise within it in this country. It is obvious from the material I have read-that was some time ago and it is still back in Perth rather than here with me in Canberra; I was not inclined to have it faxed over at Government expense to review it, because I suppose Senator Walsh has had an influence on me-that this company has a lot to learn. It really needs to sit down and talk to the people in the trade union movement. By talking to only one side of the political spectrum it is being seriously misinformed on how to go about things.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw an analogy with one of the companies Senator Cooney mentioned in his contribution to the debate, Skilled Engineering Pty Ltd. Maybe 10 years ago we could have conducted a similar debate about Skilled Engineering's attempts to get into the industry as a body-hire company-or as a carcass broker, which was the terminology we in the trade union movement used at that time. It sought to enter the industry by a variety of methods but it woke up to itself fairly quickly in the piece because it found out it was making very little progress. It was not going out and making money, making profits for itself and any shareholders it may have represented; all it was doing was creating confrontation-for the workers, the full time employees, on the job; for the people it hired; for the employers and so on. So it backed off and sat down and talked with the trade union movement. To the best of my knowledge Skilled Engineering is operating in every State in Australia and it is operating in a volatile industry-the metal trades industry. I do not want to compare the dispute statistics of one industry with those of another, but we know that the metal trades industry can, when it wants to pull on a turn, pull on a turn.

We have heard the name of John Halfpenny mentioned. It might surprise Senator McGauran to learn that Skilled Engineering was able to negotiate an agreement-and the agreement is still operating-with the union John Halfpenny used to represent before he was elected Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council. That company knows how to manage people, and it knows how to manage industrial relations. It has made it its business to know the operators in the industries in which it seeks to work, and from my isolated background of Western Australia I make the comment that I doubt whether the principals in Troubleshooters Available really have got to that stage. If they are the individuals in the gallery, I advise them to have a look at this matter. If they did talk not only with the employers but also with the unions they would never have put out the contract of employment document they have. SPEECH.PARA: I (the undersigned) acknowledge and agree that there is no relationship of Employer-Employee with TROUBLESHOOTERS AVAILABLE and that TROUBLESHOOTERS AVAILABLE does not guarantee me any work. If that is industrial relations in Australia in the twentieth century when we have a system of conciliation and arbitration, I will eat my hat. I will have to buy one first because I do not own one. Not in any shape or form does it measure up to the demands of Australian society. It is more like a document which would emanate from the New Right organisation. Speaking of the New Right, Senator Short in his opening comments made mention of another Victorian dispute which is now recognised as somewhat of a landmark case in the industrial relations scene. From memory, at the time of the dispute Senator Short dealt with some facts. Today Senator Short, followed up by Senator McGauran, dealt with accusations and we were left very short on facts-apart from one poster which was held up and displayed but which we have all seen before because the company, Troubleshooters Available, sent it to me and I understand to all honourable senators.

Senator Cooney in his contribution referred, as does the first paragraph of the agreement to contract, to what the court had said about whether particular individuals associated with Troubleshooters Available were employees or subcontractors, and the court very clearly determined that they were employees.

—That is what Senator Cooney is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: 3. I (the undersigned) hereby acknowledge and agree that TROUBLESHOOTERS AVAILABLE does not cover me in respect of Workcare, the onus of responsibility and liability in respect of insurance is mine only. Further, I have no claim on TROUBLESHOOTERS AVAILABLE in respect of Workcare.

Is it any wonder that there is opposition from the trade union movement when we see contracts such as his floating around? Is it any wonder indeed that there is opposition? That opposition will continue until the company can sit down and work out some rational and reasonable agreements with the major parties involved. I am sure that that can be done. As I mentioned, with Skilled Engineering it has been done.

Some criticism was directed at the Government on this matter. The point must be made that at no stage has this company put any specific proposals to the Commonwealth Government in relation to the matters that it is associated or involved with. Even if it did, it would run into some constitutional problems because, for one thing, the Government, like any other employer, operates under the conciliation and arbitration system. This company is not registered under the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister refused to talk to them, Senator.

—Senator Short supports the conciliation and arbitration system. But this company is not registered under that system and, to the best of my knowledge, has not in any way sought registration. The principals of the company have, from time to time, relayed their concerns to government officers, but they have not-and it is worth repeating-put any specific proposals to the Government at any time.
