SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion of urgency brought forward by Senator Jim Short from Victoria on the subject of the lack of support from the Victorian Labor Government and from the Federal Labor Government for a firm which not just recently but for 10 years or more has been under very considerable pressure from the trade union movement, but which is endeavouring to preserve in the building industry some of the efficiencies that were in danger of being lost because of the attacks by the trade union movement on the subcontract system.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be very easy to spend the whole of my quarter of an hour simply dealing with the random points which have been raised in response to this debate. But let me first of all go back to what this debate is really about. The matter has been brought forward by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition because we believe that the pressures which for more than a decade have been put upon this firm are, in fact, attacks on individual freedom in this country. They are attacks on the rights of people to earn their living as they wish. That alone makes it a very important issue.

Perhaps of more broad interest and importance to the Australian community, which tends not to be interested so much in theoretical ideas of freedom, is that we are talking about efficiency in the building industry and the cost at which people get the houses that they have to buy and the other buildings that they have to buy and occupy. I remind the Senate that the building and construction industry in Australia can be divided into two parts. There is that part which is concerned with building the houses in which Australians live. Most of us live in detached cottages. In that area of the building industry Australia is the most efficient country in the world. We build those buildings as efficiently as anywhere in the world and more efficiently than almost any other country. In Australia it takes between 5 1/2 and 9 1/2 man hours to build one square metre of housing; in the United Kingdom it takes 14 to 20 man hours; in Sweden it takes 11 to 12 man hours; and in the United States, which is the only country that comes close to us, it takes 6 1/2 to 9 man hours. That means that in a country which puts a high premium on home ownership and having a high standard of accommodation the building industry has been able to deliver. The Government, through its poor control of land availability, through its high tax policies, through its high interest rate policies, may put the cost of home ownership out of the hands of many Australians, but the fact is that the building industry does not. We have a very efficient building industry because it operates on a subcontract basis.

On the other side of the building industry, the commercial building sector, Australia is a disgrace. The comparable figures show that Australia does very badly when we look at the way building is conducted around the world. If we look at some quite simple statistics that were produced by the master builders, now in their new building and construction organisation-they commissioned a work by Professor Ireland-we find a horrifying description of the building industry at that commercial end.

Let me put it in terms that will make sense to every wage and salary earner in this country and to every building worker. Professor Ireland states that, if there was no lost time, workers on central business district sites could have their wages increased by 119 per cent and projects would cost no more. The record of stoppages is so bad that the wages that are being paid to the men who work on the sites could be more than doubled and it would not add to the cost of the building. Last year Mr Kelty said that the building industry was bad everywhere in the world. In Australia, according to this survey, 17 per cent of working time on central business district building projects was lost because of industrial disputes. In the United States and in the United Kingdom, the figure was closer to zero than to one per cent. In Australia we lost 10 per cent of time because of inclement weather. What is the situation in the United States and in the United Kingdom? It is somewhere around 2 per cent. Is that not remarkable? In other words, in a country with the extraordinarily favourable climatic conditions of Australia, we lose five times as much working time on building sites because of inclement weather as they do in the United States and the United Kingdom.

We are talking about a threat by the building unions over a decade or more to try to make that bad section of the industry worse. It is part of the push. We heard it today from Senator McKiernan, who, with horror, incorporated a standard form of contract into the Hansard. Yet we know that the working men and women of Australia can afford, in the main, decent housing because we have efficient building practices and not the inefficiencies which are imposed on the industry by the building unions in the commercial market.

This is a struggle which affects every Australian. The truth of the matter is that the Government of Victoria and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia have refused to take any interest in the pressure which the building unions have put upon this organisation, even though the rights of the Australian people, the economic interests of the Australian people, are being threatened by the pressure against subcontracting generally as a feature of the union movement today.

I am sick of it. When I rise to debate in this place an issue that touches trade unions, inevitably the lawyers who have made their money out of the trade unions, such as Senator Cooney, and the people who have been trade union officials, such as Senator McKiernan and the next Labor speaker, Senator Childs, will get up and accuse us of union bashing. I just want to say, when we talk about the less savoury end of the trade union movement, that I, in this place and elsewhere, have praised unions such as the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia which is trying to take the vehicle building industry into the twenty-first century. I have praised the changes in the metal workers unions that are looking at award restructuring and doing constructive things. But I make no apology, like Senator Short, for bringing into this place those instances of trade union abuse of power.

Senator Short talked about the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. We got criticised for dealing with matters which were sub judice. Let me deal with the case of Dollar Sweets which is not sub judice any more because it has been through the courts. Let me remind the Senate, and Senator Childs who will follow me in this debate, that that case was also about the oppression of workers by other workers and not just an attack on a small businessman and an employer. Let me read from the judgment of the Victorian Supreme Court about some of the things that were uncovered in that dispute. There was an incident involving drivers which ceased when Mr Lendon contacted the police. The judgment states:
A fortnight after . . . as Mr Lendon was delivering sugar to the plaintiff's premises-
a truck driver delivering sugar-
he was obliged to stop his vehicle because of the presence of another vehicle . . .
We then get a description of the pickets. The judgment continues:

. . . the second defendant came to Mr Lendon's truck and attempted to pull the side mirror off the truck. Mr Lendon began to get out of his truck and while doing so the third-named defendant, Jacques Lahausse, punched him from behind with the consequence that he fell to the ground.

Then a number of women who were in the picket line punched and kicked Mr. Lendon. The fourth-named defendant . . . ripped a hair piece from his head, which he said caused him to bleed. Mr. Lendon could not break free from his assailants until two other truck drivers came to his assistance. The uncontradicted evidence is that Mr. Lendon has, as a result of the assault, been required to have an operation on the retina of his eye, and now wears glasses.

I do not have time to go on with other examples from Canberra of the same sort of brutality and oppression. I just say to the Senate that the Australian Labor Party and honourable senators opposite do themselves less than justice when they refuse to acknowledge that there is an ugly side to trade unions and industrial disputes. Those of us who are prepared to acknowledge the virtues of the trade union movement when they exist are entitled to bring forward abuses when they exist.

Senator Cooney attempted to say that we should not be debating this matter because it is sub judice. I make the point that the difficulties that we debate in this place are difficulties that have been going on to a greater or lesser extent-the situation has come and gone-for 15 years, back to 1973. Senator McKiernan has asked why this urgency motion was brought forward today. I will tell him why it was brought forward today. When Senator Short asked me whether he could bring it forward at the very beginning of the session I said no, that we had other matters to debate and he would have to wait until later in the session. He has been pressing me ever since. Only early this week did I say, `All right, you can have a go'. That is the secret of the timing of this matter! Senator Cooney should be more careful when he comes in here and chastises the Opposition.

He accused Troubleshooters Available, under parliamentary privilege, of not paying WorkCare-a very serious accusation which goes to the agency's credit and its reputation in the community. Yet my understanding is that this matter has been litigated in the Supreme Court and the Supreme Court has held that these people are not employees. Final orders have not yet been made and discussions are still to be had with the WorkCare authorities. But the fact is that these people are not common law employees, although some could be caught by the deeming provisions of the WorkCare legislation. So let us have a little more care on the other side of the chamber as well.

I turn now to Senator McLean who, sadly, once again when it comes to the crunch, has, as always, run with the Left. He claimed that this was of concern to the extreme Right; that it was only a first case; that we were dealing with the question of the subcontractor versus the union approach to things; and that it was part of some deliberate campaign. I say in response to Senator McLean that this sort of behaviour has been going on since 1973. There have been attempts to provide avenues of work for people who do not want to be regarded as employees, who wish to carry on businesses on their own behalf and who wish to contribute to the flexibility, efficiency and productivity of the building industry in Australia. When we get an obstruction of those efforts over a 15-year period I find that it strains my credulity to suggest that, in some peculiar way, debating that matter in this Senate in October 1988 is in some way a plot. It is an absurd response from Senator McLean and I am disappointed that he should make that point.

This debate is about union power versus worker power. The subcontractors who work for Troubleshooters are all paid above award wages and, indeed, are all union members. I might say that that muddies the stream. Because of the pressures that can be put on people in the building industry they have accepted that all of them, whether they are independent subcontractors or not, have to be members of a union, so they are all paying union dues. Troubleshooters is not being attacked here; it is the 7,000 union members who, over the years, have obtained work through this agency as independent subcontractors. The real reason the building unions dislike the subcontracting system is quite clear. Their advocate at the building industry inquiry being conducted by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission said that the unions' opposition to the system was because it `promoted individualism and competition where they really wanted solidarity to the organisation'. This matter is about solidarity to organisations and not about individual rights, competition, or individualism. That is the quality that we need if we are to reverse the long term slide of this country-we want individual effort and competition.

Again I ask the Senate to compare the efficiency of our home building sector, which has that competition, with the gross inefficiency, waste and abuse which occur in the commercial building sector and which led this Labor Government to have the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) deregistered. The abuses were so bad that the Labor governments of Canberra, Melbourne, and Sydney at the time combined to deregister the BLF. The benefits of that contract system were put by Commissioner Burns in the 1979 report of the New South Wales Enquiry into the Cottage Industry. He said:

It is not because of any reverence for those two concepts of `free enterprise' and `the marketplace' that I am convinced that the present practice in the cottage building industry should be left alone. It is because they so obviously work.

This Government has taken to talking about a flexible labour market. The type of set-up that Troubleshooters represents is at the cutting edge of greater labour market flexibility all around the world. Yet here we have the unions and a Labor government working to undermine this flexibility-not in the interests of protecting workers but in the interests of protecting the power of the union officials in the building industry. This has been written about in the Age and in the Business Review Weekly, without people crying out that it is a matter which is sub judice. The truth of the matter is that in this debate the sub judice argument was used to try to obscure the real interests of the Australian people that are dealt with in the urgency motion brought forward by Senator Short. I commend it to the Senate. I fear that the Australian Democrats will run with the Labor Party on this. It is a disgrace when we think of their claim that they look to the interests of small business in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion brought forward by the Opposition talks of `the necessity for the Hawke Government to take urgent action to assist in preventing further disruption' in the Victorian building industry. What are the facts? As Senator Cooney has already established, the facts are that, normally, we should not be discussing the issue as it is to be dealt with by the Federal Court of Australia. But I heard an interjection from Senator Stone to the effect that Troubleshooters Available cannot get justice from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Two Opposition senators, Senator McGauran and Senator Short, referred to another legal case where there is a damages action against Troubleshooters Available which is to be heard before a jury in the Supreme Court of Victoria. The Opposition has been free in talking about these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the debate should take place because it highlights the difference between the Opposition and the Government. The Opposition has picked Troubleshooters Available because it seems to conform with the extremist industrial relations policy of the Liberal Party of Australia. The Opposition is attracted to it because it is an award breaker, undermining the long established industrial standards. This is a characteristic of the Troubleshooters Available industrial sham-and that is what it is.

At a time when Victoria has a thriving building industry, nurtured by the Cain Government, this Opposition wants us to leap back into the past and back a company that wants to suck profits from the building industry and give nothing in return. In contrast, this Government, as the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, says, has award restructuring as the central plank of the program of labour market reform, as set out in a paper released with the Budget last August. It rejects the simplistic and unworkable deregulation philosophy of the Opposition and presents a cooperative approach to industrial relations reform and workplace change. The choice is clear. It is cooperation or confrontation. That is the answer to what Senator Chaney has just said. The choice is building skills in the building industry, restructuring, creating secure conditions to achieve change and a shared benefit of increased productivity, or the reverse-anarchy. This proposal coming from the Opposition points very much in the direction of anarchy.

The conditions of contract that Troubleshooters Available requires its workers to sign show it to be a feral industrial enterprise. It is a tough industry, but Troubleshooters is like a feral organisation within the industry. Senator Chaney referred to the less savoury aspects of the trade union movement. I say that the activities of Troubleshooters are a less savoury activity of employers. The worker-and I emphasise the worker-who signs the document, signs away rights. The worker who signs the document is purported to be self-employed, as is indicated in Senator Short's motion. But if one looks at clause 6 of the document that Senator McKiernan has incorporated, one sees that all that happens is that the worker takes an hourly rate that is higher but loses a whole range of award entitlements, and that is what it is all about. For example, clause 7 of the agreement to the contract, which I previously referred to, states:

it is agreed that I (the undersigned) must carry out all work that I agree to do with the agency Troubleshooters Available in a workmanlike manner and Troubleshooters Available is thereby guaranteed against faulty workmanship.
It goes on:

All work must be made good. Further, I agree to cover the work (where necessary) for Public Liability, Accident Insurance, Long Service Leave, Holiday Pay, sick Pay and superannuation, and have no claims on Troubleshooters Available in respect of the above.

All risks and liability are with the worker. Workers are only paid, of course, for time worked-the other significant undermining of the award conditions in the building industry. But of course they are not self-employed, and that is the important thing. I believe the court case that is projected will establish that. That is the important point about it. The workers have none of the characteristics of a genuine person running a small business. Generally speaking, they work under the direction of a foreman as any other time worker does. They do not tender for a job. There is no negotiation about the price for the work they will do, as would be the case in a genuine business. There is no business relationship. They have no overheads. Other than the flat rate they receive there is no question of profit or loss. All these normal business criteria are absent because we are talking about a phony self-employment, and I assert that. I believe the trade union movement clearly asserts it. I believe the courts will come to that decision.

When we have Senator Chaney saying that there is need for flexibility of the labour movement, what we are really dealing with is an attempt to take away all the infrastructure of the award by virtue of a simple higher payment being made. Of course there will always be workers who will take a narrow view of the condition in the industry, until they are hurt because of their opting out of the general conditions of the award that are designed to protect all the workers in the industry. That is the situation that we face. It has been said that Troubleshooters has made representations. We know it has had a highly placed publicity campaign, but I am informed that, despite what Senator Chaney has just said, at no stage has the company put specific proposals to the Government. The principals of the company have only relayed their concern to relevant departmental officers.

We know that the Commonwealth Government cannot do anything in this situation. It is a Victorian jurisdiction. The matter is confined to Victoria. Clearly this is a red herring because of Liberal Party industrial philosophy. One of the major concerns of the unions, as I understand it, relates to the employment relationships created by the operations of Troubleshooters, which avoid the application of awards, agreements, industrial legislation and create a special class of worker. That it what we are talking about-a special class of worker. The conflict created on site by this duality is a major source of conflict in Victoria. An attempt is being made to create a special class of worker.

Is it any wonder that the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Victorian Trades Hall Council are leading this struggle against the breakdown of building industry conditions? They are not opposed to the legitimate companies that engage in labour-only forms of contract, because they conform to all the award requirements. If people need additional workers for a concrete pour, companies enter into contracts, but they pay all the award conditions. That is the qualitative difference between those companies, such as Skilled Engineering Pty Ltd, to name one, and the company that is being referred to today. I believe that if business, government and trade unions-indeed, everyone-wants an orderly award structure, predictability so that long term investment and planning can be made, cooperation to restructure complex industries like the building industry, apprenticeship creation-and, remember, these is no apprenticeship creation with this type of company-and the upgrading of skills, we will reject this type of time bomb that this company is trying to introduce into industrial relations.

The problem is that the Guy Fawkeses in the Opposition are very keen on having this matter blow up to give them the confrontation that fits in with their philosophy. I think Senator McLean has put their weights up. He pointed out that they are thwarted by their moves in the recent industrial legislation, so they now continue with the famous voluntary agreements clauses 5.9 and 5.10 of their industrial relations policy and their obsession with voluntary agreements. I cannot spend as much time as I would like to on that matter and, as I say, we have just gone through that debate. We have new legislation that provides a framework to overcome even the sort of thing that Senator Chaney referred to.

If we are to have change and improvements in such a difficult industry as the building industry, we will only get it by cooperation. We will not get cooperation from the vast majority of people in the industry if we promote a company that is only concerned with taking money out of the building industry. That is all a company does when, by paying a higher rate of pay, it tries to buy off all the other conditions of the award. A company does not put into the industry when it is doing that. All it does is pay a high over-award payment and it then tries to abrogate all the award conditions that the workers would normally enjoy.

Senator McGauran quoted the Australian Small Business Association as being in the forefront of the campaign. That gives away the New Right aspect of the campaign that we have in this case. Senator McGauran referred to the 20,000 companies that should be concerned in Victoria. I would say to all those small business people, `Watch very carefully for an industrial relations policy that can only inflame the whole of an industry'-in this case, a very significant industry, the building industry. All small business people who rely on the building industry have a guarantee of confrontation if this proposal is extended. In other words, this will be the position if we are not successful in saying that workers in this situation as proposed are being misled. We must say that we do want an industry in which there is proper consideration of the infrastructure, where employers, as part of their responsibility to the industry, contribute to building the considerations that are necessary for the prosperity of the industry.

This Government, I think, is very proud of the way that we have cooperation in industry after industry. We have the cooperation that has been expressed in industry plans in industry after industry. Although the building industry will be a very difficult industry to reconcile because of its very history, the reconciliation will only come about if there is goodwill, if we are not seeking to have confrontation which is disguised under the Liberal Party's slogan of individualism.

Senator Chaney, in the conclusion of his remarks, referred to the problems of pickets. I suggest to the honourable senator that if he takes the overall position of industrial relations in Australia-indeed, if he takes the industrial relations position in Victoria, since we came to government-he will see that there has been a vast reduction in industrial disputes.

However, there is another side I would like to express in the remaining minute or two that I have to speak. It has been my experience, and I know it continues to this day, that people are tramped from jobs every day by employers using all sorts of subtle techniques for getting rid of people who are either outspoken or not liked for one reason or another. I am referring to all sorts of people-creative people and dynamic people who have dared to differ from the strong discipline that exists in many factories, plants and building sites. So there is another side which I have not time to develop here but I challenge Senator Chaney: I believe I could produce, given time, thousands of cases where ordinary people are hurt because of the action of employers. They have only their unions to defend them. Senator Chaney has to come in here time and time again with the Dollar Sweets case and a couple of other cases. They are part of the New Right agenda. They do not prove anything, because the majority of people-unfortunately, ordinary people working in industry-have great difficulty and very little democracy. That is something this Government is seeking to change in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have just a few minutes at my disposal before the time for this debate expires. I do not want to go over all the issues that have been dealt with in the debate today. So said Mr Groves. He has a pretty good track record to prove that, as has Troubleshooters. As Senator Chaney mentioned, it has caused the employment in the building industry of 7,000 subcontractors-independent small businessmen-during the years in which it has been in operation.

Senator Cooney made comments about the Work Care situation confronting Troubleshooters. In my view, he misled the Senate in what he said. Time prevents me from going any further on this matter, Madam Acting Deputy President. I commend this urgency motion to the Senate. It is about the right of the average Australian who wants to be independent to remain independent, to have a job. The payments provided for in this Bill, $12,400.6m, account for about 15 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1988-89. As such, these payments constitute a major element of the Commonwealth's Budget.

In combination with the general purpose capital assistance provided for under the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988 and the global borrowing limits agreed at the Loan Council meeting, they have a major bearing on the spending and borrowing of State governments. The level of assistance provided in the Bill involves a reduction of $650m against the forward estimates at the time of the Premiers Conference. The base funding that was agreed at the Conference is to be adjusted for the actual increase in the CPI in the year to the March quarter 1989.

General revenue assistance to be provided in 1988-89 will also be reduced so as to recoup 90 per cent of the revenue available to the States and the Northern Territory as a result of the removal of the payroll tax exemption for Commonwealth Government business enterprises. In 1988-89 it is estimated that the additional savings to the Commonwealth from this measure will be $179m. However, because the States will retain 10 per cent of the additional collections, the net effect of this measure will be to enhance their fiscal capacity.

As the Commonwealth has emphasised at both the 1987 and 1988 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings, it is essential that all levels of government restrain their spending and borrowing in order to restrain domestic demand, reduce the call on domestic savings and arrest the build up in foreign debt. Encompass the Northern Territory on the same basis as the States;

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Childs:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the report on proposed changes to the southern bluefin tuna fishery management plan by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology there has emerged the resolution of an issue of equity produced by Labor Government actions and corrected only because of Senate response. It is the Senate Committee's response to which I am referring. Credit is due particularly to my colleague Senator Brian Archer for his role in initiating this inquiry.
—Senator who?

—Senator Brian Archer, from Tasmania, who worked always towards the negotiated solution which has finally emerged. My appreciation also goes to my colleagues-the Chairman, the other members of the Committee-and to our efficient Committee secretariat for the part they played. The problem facing Australian fishing is complex and critical. The fishery is under immediate and urgent threat. The stock has been overfished. The biomass is at a critically low level. Fishing by Australians, New Zealanders, Japanese and by fishermen from other nations has produced the crisis. I think all members of the Committee accept and support the need for concerted action to reduce fishing for southern bluefin tuna as a matter of urgency if the fishery is to survive at all. What we have considered in this Committee's reference is a different matter: the fairness of the arrangements, the equity, regarding where the fishing restrictions will fall. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) had proposed, as part of his solution, that certain fishermen, many of them from my State of New South Wales, now fishing for small amounts of tuna should have those rights removed as part of his new management plan. His officers were quite unable to justify such an approach when questioned, although they did lay out the dangers they saw in the entry of new fishermen to the fishing of southern bluefin tuna.

SPEECH.PARA: In the end we were able to negotiate with the Minister. We support the move to limit catches of southern bluefin tuna. We share the sense of urgency which the Minister and his officers transmitted to us. We share the sense of urgency which the situation demands of all honourable senators. We share and support the Minister's decision to require all those who hold quota to limit their fishing in line with the new overall fishing limits which are to be laid down. But we were not satisfied with the arrangements as they related to certain fishermen who traditionally have taken small amounts of bluefin tuna and who have reported those catches properly on the prescribed forms as laid down by the regulations. We insisted, and the Minister finally agreed, that the small fishermen operating within special quota entitlements should not have part of their livelihood removed. It was a matter of some convenience that we had a disallowance motion in the Senate up our sleeves, in reserve. I must say that that helped in the negotiations no end.

I am talking about the small fishermen, many from the south coast of New South Wales, who fish only occasionally for southern bluefin tuna and who do so legally. They saw no justice in yet one more move by the Labor Government to disadvantage them in a way which was not equitable. We agreed that there had to be a great reduction in the activity within the fishery. We agreed that only those who had been fishing for southern bluefin tuna, who had a history of having fished for southern bluefin tuna, should have a quota in this new crisis and this new emergency. What was worrying the Minister was that, under the regulations as they existed, up to, I think, a couple of thousand fishermen could have entered, even if they had never fished for southern bluefin tuna. Those fishermen did not face a loss of livelihood. It is not as if they had been taking the tuna and were faced with the loss of that catch. They would have been new entrants. The Committee agreed that those new entrants were not welcome in view of the critical position facing the fishery and the biomass of southern bluefin tuna.

It is to the credit of the Minister that he has been prepared to deal with the Senate Committee, armed as it was with a contingent notice to disallow his regulation. Nevertheless, he dealt with the Committee and we were able to reach a negotiated solution. That solution will mean that certain fishermen in the small fishing ports along the south coast of New South Wales, fishermen who have taken southern bluefin tuna, who have reported their catches, who are known to the Department and who have an established record will now share in the smaller quota. They will be able to take small amounts of tuna, as they have done. They will be able to report then, as they have done. They will pay the licence fees, as they have done. They, too, will be allowed to continue their activity. I think that is a fairer solution.

Whatever the reason that prompted the Minister to deal with us, I think we have to thank him. We have a solution which will allow the Minister to pursue the protection of the fishery as he wants to do. It will allow all those who hold quota to continue to fish, albeit with smaller quotas than they have enjoyed until now. We have delivered to many small fishermen, particularly on the east coast, who otherwise would have suffered unnecessarily and unfairly, a much fairer set of arrangements than those originally proposed.

This is one of those committee references which reflect well upon the Senate. I remind honourable senators that the reference was accepted by the Committee only three or four weeks ago and it was dealt with expeditiously. It was possible to hold one major public hearing and several private hearings with officers and with the Minister. It was possible to report to the Senate and to bring to the Senate a resolution of the problem. It is the way in which Senate committees should work. Again, I want to say to the secretariat and to my colleagues on the Committee that I think it reflects well upon the whole Senate committee system. I am delighted with the report but most especially delighted with the outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 12 April 1988 when the fisheries notices relative to the curtailment of southern bluefin tuna fishing were signed with the effect of removing all the rights to fish for southern bluefin tuna by all those who had previously had entitlements to catch either one tonne or five tonne quotas under the original southern bluefin tuna management plan of 1985. Between 12 April 1988 and June 1988 considerable discussion and negotiation took place. The result was that those to be divested claimed that they had been treated unfairly. There was never any question that the total catch of southern bluefin tuna had to be reduced. We all agreed on that and we agreed that it should be done drastically. The question was whether cuts should be made to all those with licences. As my colleague Senator Peter Baume has already said, we discussed the question of equity.

SPEECH.PARA: It became clear early on that information was available to the scientists that was not known to the fishermen, that the Australian Fisheries Service had plans that also needed to be spelt out fully to both the fishermen and the scientists, and that the fishermen and State interests wanted to be heard and wanted to know what was going on.

The notices of disallowance were given in the Senate on our return to the Senate on 23 and 24 August. We then proceeded to arrange a meeting to hear the evidence. The evidence was provided and resulted in the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, settling on two issues: firstly, that huge cuts in the catching quota were absolutely essential if the fishery were to survive; and, secondly, that they should be borne by all those who were participating in it. The Committee acknowledged that the original arrangements had been very loose but that they had been necessary as a means of getting a closure to the original agreement in 1985. After meeting with the Australian Fisheries Service representatives for a second time the Committee then met with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and put to him the proposal that he ultimately approved. I thank him publicly for that.

The handling of the problem was a most successful operation and gave all the parties the opportunity to understand one another and to remember that at all times it is the resource that must be preserved. The concurrent negotiations over international catches established the seriousness, and the comments of Dr Harden-Jones that the only safe catch is a zero catch brought everybody up with a severe jerk. The solution provides that every fisherman in Australia who has a record of commitment to catching southern bluefin tuna since the plan was instituted in 1985 and who has a licence or an entitlement will still be able to fish for southern bluefin tuna. The simple evidence to be produced will be the CR.2 form and that is the entitlement.

What else came from the inquiry was that there is still dangerously little current knowledge of the southern bluefin tuna, its travels, breeding and habits and that much more research in this area is absolutely essential. It further arose that State fishing authorities or cooperatives, if they owned or leased a quota, could cover any of their members who produced a genuine incidental, untargeted catch. Hopefully, we have not only fairly and equitably resolved the issue but gained an understanding of the problems of this and other areas of the fishing industry that may prevent other similar problems in the future. I thank the other members of the Committee and the Committee staff for the way they carried out their jobs. I also thank all the witnesses who came from various parts of Australia to appear before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Archer and Senator Peter Baume, I too want to record my thanks to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in developing its report, Proposed Changes to the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan. I want to specifically mention the work of Senator Childs, the Chairman of the Committee. As I have said on previous occasions, a lot of responsibility rests with an individual senator when he holds the position of chair. That person must coordinate and ensure that all the interests in whatever area the Committee is covering are represented and given a fair hearing. Senator Childs certainly did that and I am sure that my colleagues would join me in commending him on his work. Mention was made of the staff of the Committee, who put in a tremendous effort in a very short space of time to bring the report, Proposed Changes to the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan, to the point that it is now at. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), despite some of the comments Senator Peter Baume made about him and the actions that the Government undertook in the initial stages prior to the inquiry, did cooperate in every way with the Committee in reaching what seems to the Committee at least and certainly, I would suggest, to a large number of witnesses who appeared before the hearing, to be a satisfactory settlement to a very difficult problem. It is a problem that concerns not only the individual fisherpersons. A lot of people make their living from catching fish, but this report and the actions of the Minister on southern bluefin tuna go much wider than that. As Senator Peter Baume and Senator Archer have said, the stock of this particular species is in some jeopardy. If the Government had not instituted some action we could in a very short space of time have seen the complete depletion of the southern bluefin tuna.

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence was given to the Committee about the catch and how it had escalated over the years leading to a peak in the mid-1970s. Because the stock was overfished it started on a rapid and massive decline. While that decline in the catch was happening the price of the product was actually increasing. We had evidence given to us that one fish brought to one witness $50,000. This was to satisfy the Japanese sashimi market. That in itself is an attraction for many individuals to enter the field, a field that has declining stocks.

The Government obviously had to take some action. The action that was contemplated in the first instance of not allowing a quota for those holders of five-tonne and one tonne quotas was deemed by some to be inequitable. I might say as a senator from Western Australia that the Committee, together with the Minister, has come up with a recommendation and a solution that will please the Western Australian industry and Western Australian Government. They advocated to us that when cutting quotas we ought to cut them right across the board. That is indeed what we have attempted to do. Whilst we have reached a compromise solution on this occasion, a lot more investigation has to be done into this particular aspect of the fishing industry.

We heard evidence that the stock is declining. We also had heard that there was insufficient evidence available-Senator Archer went into that matter in some detail-about stock and breeding grounds. There is some confusion within scientific circles in the industry. The particular species of fish will have to be continually looked at by government and by all connected with the industry if a catastrophe is not to occur through the wiping out of the species. The Committee has done a very good job under some pressure not only from industry but also from government and a number of vested interests. The vested interests comprise not only the people who are interested in the money that can be earned from the industry but also people who are interested in nature and the protection of a species of fish that has as much right to exist on this earth as honourable senators do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume and Senator Archer addressed themselves particularly to the matter of equity in the access to a rapidly failing southern bluefin tuna stock. Of course, equity is quite important. One might note of course that if the stock were to fail altogether so that there was no fish we would all be very equitable and all have exactly zero access to tuna.
—That would have to be one of the options.
—That is one of the options, as Senator Peter Baume has pointed out.
—But for everybody.

—It would be a zero option for everybody. I stress the observation that both the Government and the Opposition are committed to a form of growth economics which demands that we have more people who demand more from the environment and that as a consequence the equit- able share of what is left becomes smaller and smaller. What we see in the case of the southern bluefin tuna is simply one of many examples of the failure of the basic growth economic model which both the Government and Opposition are following. As Senator McKiernan has pointed out, as the stock declines the value of each individual fish goes up. So, the market system which the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Button and Senator Walsh extol every day in their respective Houses of parliament does nothing whatsoever to protect the environment and the stocks of fish. I draw attention to clause 1.4 of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee itself is very concerned that not only is the existence of an economically important fishery threatened, but that the very existence of this particular tuna species is in doubt. The species has in the past been over-fished and immature fish have been taken. Further substantial cuts in total allow- able catch may be needed if stocks are going to be rebuilt.

Three factors have led to that situation. We are dealing with a migratory species, which means that we do not have complete control over stocks. The fish migrate very extensively and are fished by a number of nations. Some of those nations in the past have shown very little regard for environmental care. Japan is one nation which proceeded to fish the various whale species long after the International Whaling Commission had recommended substantial cuts, and the Japanese have not shown themselves to be particularly concerned about environmental matters generally.

The tuna fish is a species that lives for quite a long time-up to 20 years-but interestingly, and this was not known when the fishery first began in Australia, it is often eight years old before it gets to a size at which it can breed. In the early days of fishing the tuna stocks in South Australia we, along with many other countries, were taking immature species. That is one of the factors which have very significantly depleted the breeding stocks of this fish. Bernie Scott, the manager of the tuna branch of the Australian Fisheries Service, says in a paper:
Recent scientific advice indicates that the stock is in greater danger than we had first thought.
In 1982 it was estimated that the parental biomass-
that is, the number of fish over eight years old and of the breeding age-
had fallen to about one-third of its pre-fishing level. Now scientists believe it could be as low as one-fifth of the 1960 level and are predicting a further reduction.

It hasn't yet been determined whether recruitment failure has occurred-that is, such a severe reduction in the production of young fish that the stock may be unable to replenish itself-but with such a dramatic fall in the parental biomass the risk of this is enormous.
It is a risk which has to be minimised if a commercially viable fishery is to survive.
He concludes by saying:
Scientists have advised that we may also have to consider a further reduction in the total allowable catch.

He is clearly presaging a total wipe-out of this species. It is important, of course, to recognise these matters of equity, but there is an even more important underlying lesson to be learned; that is, that the growth model of the economy which says that we can have more people demanding more from the environment is simply not sustainable. This is just one example of it. It is a model which has to be rejected, which has to be turned around. The Australian Democrats would like to draw to the attention of honourable senators the model of a sustainable economy. A steady state economy which is sustainable in the long term is the only economic model that will lead us to a solution of this and many other similar problems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Second Report of the Sixty-third Session

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Cook:
That the following Sessional Order, contained in the Report, be adopted:

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, in a debate on a motion for the suspension of any Standing or Sessional Order a Senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 30 minutes after the moving of the motion the question on the motion shall then be put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say from the outset that I find it decidedly disturbing that the Australian Democrats, and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) in particular, would suggest to the Standing Committee on Procedure that we introduce into this chamber by way of a standing order the prospect of having the gag put without debate. I well remember Senator Don Chipp, as he then was, saying ever so often that he was here as a reasonable man to hear reasonable argument and to keep others honest.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder how the Democrats propose to weigh in the balance the arguments put by one side or another in respect of the suspension of standing orders when they do not know the arguments in favour of the suspension. Somebody on our side, such as Senator Peter Baume, might well have a compelling reason for seeking the suspension of standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sure to be compelling.

—As Senator Baume quite properly interjects, it would be certain to be compelling. But Senator Haines suggests that the suspension of standing orders ought not be debated, and that would deny him the opportunity to put his reasons. If this chamber is to function as a living, real chamber, it is imperative that people's arguments be put in a proper way. Argument ought to be put for the suspension of standing orders. If it is the view of the Government or anybody else that standing orders ought not be suspended, their arguments ought to be put also. In this way we can have reasoned and intelligent debate which allows honourable senators, irrespective of how they vote, at least to weigh in the balance the arguments of one side or the other.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that it was the view of the Procedure Committee, which I think has now been overtaken with new membership, that that proposition be put aside but that a time limit be provided. The Committee suggests that time limits may make the rule of relevance more readily enforceable. It has been a matter of contention, very often subject to points of order, that the arguments put for or against the suspension of standing orders are in force not of the argument relating to the suspension but of the substance of the debate that should occur subsequent to the suspension being agreed to. The Committee has suggested that rules of relevance will be more easily identified if there is a time limit. That is not a view that I share. I do not underestimate the competence or the sensitivity of the President or his Deputy or, in turn, his deputies in making determinations as to whether or not a debate is within the realms of relevance.

The Committee suggests a time limit for the debate of 30 minutes, with a limit of five minutes for each speaker. It draws upon the experience of the House of Representatives, where a motion for the suspension of standing orders may not be debated for more than 25 minutes, with the first two speakers being limited to 10 minutes and other speakers to five minutes. It is my experience that it is quite impossible to put a cogent and detailed argument in five minutes, particularly given that most arguments in support of the suspension of standing orders are put for a detailed and urgent reason. I cannot imagine how anybody could in five minutes persuade the Senate that the normal business ought to be suspended for the purpose of bringing on something else as a matter of urgency.

But there is a more fundamental question which ought to be addressed; that is, whether or not we ought to continue the inexorable march towards reducing the time available for all speakers within the chamber. There has been a trend-an inevitable trend, I suspect-to cut back on the speaking time available to senators because of the amount of legislation brought before the chamber. I do not imagine there is any way that the amount of legislation coming before us will diminish, and so short of finding another solution that means, inevitably, that within the time for which the chamber presently sits there will be less time available to each speaker. There are perhaps two other approaches, one being that we increase the hours of sitting on the days we do sit and the other being that we increase the number of days we sit.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the answer.

—Senator Baume interjects to say that he supports the proposition that we ought to sit more days. I think that argument has some validity and it has some virtue. I do not know that we could sit many more hours, given the extra activities outside the chamber that almost every senator is committed to by way of party committees or parliamentary committees. Most of us arrive in this building at 8.30 in the morning and very few of us leave before midnight. I do not know whether, in the days we do sit, there is more time available, but I suspect that we can find more days. Of course, the great difficulty is that that diminishes the contribution one can make in one's own State, in one's own electorate.
—What about Wednesday nights?

—I believe we should sit Wednesday nights. I have never been able to understand the logic behind our rising at 7.30 on a Wednesday, a broadcast day. It seems to me to be absolutely absurd. The object of parliamentary broadcasts is to provide people with an opportunity to hear the level and persuasion of the debate within the chamber, but on the one night we are broadcast we rise at 7.30. That seems to defeat the logic of having our proceedings broadcast in the first place. Perhaps we should rise early on a Tuesday night or a Thursday night, but certainly not on a Wednesday night. So there is a great deal of logic in the proposition of the honourable senator that we sit on a Wednesday night.

SPEECH.PARA: I find little merit in the argument that honourable senators ought to be required to speak for reduced periods. It is absurd to suggest that I could persuade Senator Jones in five minutes that the chamber ought to suspend Standing Orders for the purpose of bringing on a matter of urgency which I was seeking to bring before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you could not do that in half an hour.

—Perhaps there is a balance in between. The other concern I have about this matter is that it is proposed to be introduced for a trial basis under Sessional Orders, but the inevitability of Sessional Orders is that, inexorably, as a matter of fact, they become Standing Orders. Whenever speaking time in this chamber has been reduced on a trial basis it has never reverted to the original duration. There has never been a standing order in this chamber, to my knowledge, that has increased the speaking time of any senator. So once we accept that contraction there is no prospect of it being recovered. As one who finds it inappropriate that the speaking time be so reduced as to deny senators an opportunity to put the full force and extent of their debate, I believe that adequate and proper time ought to be available. We have seen the experience in the House of Representatives, which now has shorter speaking times. Almost every speech is seen as an emotional outburst because there is just not time to put the substance or the facts that one wishes to put. I would hope that on further deliberation this proposal is not accepted either as a sessional order or ultimately as a standing order. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY REPORTING STAFF

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 9b (2) of the Public Service Act 1922, I present on behalf of the President a report on the operation of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for the year ending 30 June 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have not had an opportunity to read in detail the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, but it has been proposed in some circles that there be an amalgamation of Hansard, the Joint House Department and the Parliamentary Library. My inquiries and investigations in my period on the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriation and Staffing compel me to the view that that proposition has no merit. Any savings that can be found in terms of costs or staff can be found only at a management level and, inasmuch as there is fundamentally no management level that is not in some way involved in the intrinsic and day-to-day activities of the departments, I cannot find where the cost savings would come from. When I have looked to those areas where it has been argued cost savings ought to be found, I have found that not to be the case.

Each of those departments is in itself a discrete department; each is a specialised department. The Library and those responsible for it have special skills; presumably the same applies to a very large extent to Hansard. I cannot think of anything worse than having Joint House having attached to it the Library or Hansard. We would have two professional organs of the Parliament, two professional departments, attached to the Joint House Department in some obscure way-almost like an extra limb. To my knowledge the Joint House Department has no special skills and no special ability and least of all any capacity to manage other than that which it is already managing at the present time.

Given that we have been in the new Parliament House for only a short time, I should be careful in any criticism I make of the Joint House Department, but if its capacity to run a dining room, to have a senator's office cleaned or to deal with the day-to-day functions of this Parliament is any indication of the skill and application that it would apply to the Parliamentary Library and Hansard, I would be the last to be supporting any recommendation that the departments be amalgamated.

It seems to me that the amalgamation proposal is not based on the premise of reducing costs or achieving greater efficiency; it seems to flow from that inevitable demand in society from time to time to amalgamate everything into one so that we have one central decision-making body. Each of the departments has quite separate and distinct functions which are totally incompatible with those of the other. I hope that the legislation tabled some time ago in the other chamber which proposed the amalgamation of the three departments is put aside permanently and that each of those departments is able to get on with the job it is designed to do.

I have considerable admiration for the skills of the Library, which provides the intellectual resources for the Parliament, and for the skill of Hansard for promptly, efficiently and accurately recording the words of this chamber and the various committees. I hope as the months go by I will have an opportunity and some reason to make some complimentary remarks in respect of Joint House. However, given its present performance, its response to complaints and its competence, I am not optimistic.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
