DEBATE.TITLE: AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS BILL 1988SELECT COMMITTEE ON AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS IN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 has been debated for some days, because some people are very concerned about some of the aspects of what the Australian Democrats are trying to foist on the Australian people. They are trying to foist on to the farming communities problems that should not be put on them. But the Democrats are like that. I remind honourable senators of the purposes of what we are debating here today. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill provides national legislation for the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The legislation aims to ensure that agricultural and veterinary chemical products perform as intended. The Bill attempts to minimise any possible hazard to the public, to the environment, to the users of agricultural products, and to livestock. The Bill seeks to enhance the export market potential of our agricultural products and the uniformity of assessment and registration of these products within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, with some amendments. We are very happy to debate that. We are now debating cognately a motion to set up a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. The Democrats are trying to bulldoze that motion through by some lying-in-bed arrangements, if you like, with the Government. That concerns us all, because some deal has gone on here between some of the unthinking people in the Government and the Democrats. I do not know what the payoff is. I am sure the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is at the table, is not part of any deal because I know he has the interests of certain people at heart. I feel sorry for him, being part of a government that has taken part in a dirty, little, deceitful deal that was probably set in place in the other House. I do not know whether it was set in place by Mr John Kerin. I do know whether it was set in place by Bob Hawke. I do not know who set it in place. Maybe Senator Haines, on behalf of the Democrats, agreed to do different things that will help the Government at a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Invite Mr Keating along, perhaps.

—Yes, Mr Keating is back in the country. Maybe he has done this deal. Maybe he worked it out in Manhattan. They say he is the member for Manhattan. Is that correct? He is back in town, so maybe he has done this deal. Let us look at what the Democrats are trying to do to us. They are telling us that we need a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. I am not in favour of the motion to establish a select committee. We have given many reasons why we are not in favour of it. Let us look at what the motion is about. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, be established to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the adequacy of arrangements under the legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and co-ordination systems for agricultural and veterinary chemicals;
That seems to be in the Bill. I do not know why that matter has to be looked into. Probably the Bill will be passed, and it looks at those things. Point (b) of the motion states:
the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems;

That is the other thing that the Democrats want us to look into. They also say that they want us to look into the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives. That sounds to me as though it came from Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter probably whipped that one into the motion. That is what the motion is about.

Why do the Democrats want to have this inquiry? Why do they want a select committee to duplicate so much of the work that has been done already? We said the other day that we were in favour of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, with a couple of provisos. Now we have a motion to set up an inquiry to look into chemicals and all the things that go with that.

The ridiculous part about this matter is that the Government has already set in place a study into all those things that the Democrats are talking about. The Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) is inquiring into chemical residues in agricultural products. The Democrats want to set up a similar inquiry to duplicate the work. It sounds rather foolish to me. It sounds as though it is a waste of taxpayers' money. But maybe that is what the Democrats are on about. The ASTEC study states that the quality of agricultural products with respect to chemical residues is likely to become a more important factor in the marketing of these products. We agree with that. I agree with that. It also states that the working party will consider the national and international mechanisms to ensure that appropriate standards are developed. The working party will look at the national and international implications of these standards, whether residues are a cause for consumer concern, and the opportunities for the development of new analytical techniques and new and safer agricultural and veterinary chemicals through strategic research. It will also look into other opportunities for contributions through strategic research such as the development of decontamination methods. ASTEC will report on those matters to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) by December this year.

I ask again: Why do the Democrats want to have this witch-hunt into the use of chemicals in agriculture in Australia? I will tell the Senate why. They want to do it so that they can get a few of their fringe friends, who will come out of the woodwork from everywhere, to try to denigrate the farmers of this nation, who produce 37 per cent of the export wealth of this country. They are trying to denigrate the farmers who give them a standard of living. A committee such as the Democrats are mooting will duplicate the work that is already being done. Why the Government agreed to a cognate debate I do not know. I cannot understand that at all. In agreeing to a cognate debate it is trying to cloud the issue because of some deals that have been done in the other place.

I think Senator Coulter earlier today expressed some misconceptions about chemicals and whether chemical companies were doing the right thing by the farming community or by the consumers. The Australian Financial Review of 12 October reported a keynote address given at the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia Conference recently by Dr Thayne Dutson, the President of the United States-based Council of Agricultural Science and Technology. His comments sum up the misconceptions Senator Coulter has about how, if people have a chemical free system, the situation will not basically be any different from what it is now. The report states:
Dr Thayne Dutson . . . said guarantees of chemical-free food products exploited the fact that the perceptions of consumers relating to pesticides often differed greatly from scientific facts.

I do not deny that Senator Coulter has a lot of academic ability but I think sometimes some of his thoughts on some issues regarding chemicals are clouded in such a way that he is trying to mislead people about what this inquiry would achieve.

The farming community of Australia has been responsible. Senator Panizza, my very good colleague from Western Australia who has been fighting hard for the farmers of Western Australia, has said on numerous occasions how responsible the farmers in Western Australia are. They have had a look at the contamination problem in the beef industry. All the farmers in Australia have had a look at the problems that have been created by inspectors in America who, as I said earlier today, have over-inspected Australian beef but have not really inspected their own beef. The farmers have looked at this in a proper way and they have put in their own money. The Government has offered $10m over three, four, or five years, but the farming community, and especially the beef producers, have put in their money to clean up their own industry. I think that does them great credit. I think some of the criticisms that have been made about the farming community by my colleagues at the bottom end of the chamber have not done them any credit at all.

The farming community is responsible. I would like to state again my objection to what the Democrats are on about. I repeat that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill will ensure that chemicals have a thorough testing and that they perform properly. The Australian Science and Technology Council already has an inquiry going into chemical residues in agricultural products and I think the proposal to set up a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals should be thrown out it its entirety by this chamber. I urge members of the Australian Labor Party sitting on the government benches to ask themselves what they are leading the Australian farming community into, and what they are leading our trade relations with the rest of the world into. They are lying in bed with the Democrats by accepting their proposal for a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

I reiterate that, with amendments, we support the thrust of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill but we definitely do not agree in any way with the setting up of a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals which will only duplicate the inquiry which is already being conducted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure to follow a speaker like Senator Brownhill from New South Wales.
—What are you doing with the National Party?

—He always stands up for his State and his country, which is different from what Senator Sanders does. He has been good at running down his country of birth and now he is running down his State and Australia. Senator Brownhill always stands up for his State in this place and that is what I try to do for Western Australia. Madam Acting Deputy President, I can assure you that I will not go over the matters which I have already spoken about at length regarding a cognate debate on the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and Senator Powell's motion to set up a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals. In the short time available to me I will address my remarks to the proposal by the Australian Democrats. I reiterate, as other senators have already done, that this proposal is a duplication and a waste of time and effort. It is a duplication because the Australian Science and Technology Council is coming out with its finding at the end of the year. It is also a great waste of Commonwealth money, taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that we should not be wasting taxpayers' money-our own money-on useless projects, yet here we have the Government setting up another inquiry before the results of the first inquiry have come out. We heard that there were no funds available towards the end of the last year for a national survey on pesticides. So the beef producers, rather than the horticultural industry which put producers in this situation in the first place, had to carry the cost themselves. Exporters of beef make more money out of the beef than do growers. There was no money available for that survey and we had to levy those farmers up to $18 a beast, and a higher amount for each sheep, to carry out this survey. But money is now being made available for this useless witch-hunt.

As I and other speakers have said before, this is a fishing expedition to suit the Australian Democrats' prejudices and to appease their radical supporters who come in here and make wild allegations under privilege. I notice that, while this very important Bill is being debated, the press galley is empty.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not; AAP is there.

—I can see the representative now as she has her head up from the sleeping position. Senator McKiernan may be able to see from that side of the chamber but I cannot. I apologise; there is a member in the press gallery.
—I can see her there.
—I have apologised for my mistake and I recognise that a member of the Press Gallery is there.
—Now there are two-a 100 per cent increase.

—Where is the second one? He has just come in the door. He certainly was not there earlier. When this witch-hunt is on we will have all the press on earth and all the wild allegations that are made will be printed. Yesterday probably the most important and up to date environmental policy was put in front of us by Senator Puplick. It was well received not only by us but also by the press and the general public who turned up at the briefing. Honourable senators opposite missed a very good presentation.
—We weren't invited.

—It was an open invitation; the honourable senator did not need to be invited. He can go down to the National Press Club any day. He would have enjoyed the briefing. But where is that policy reported in the press?
—Phillip Adams in the Weekend Australian.
—All right. About 20 minutes ago I went and had a look at the papers. I finally found it reported on page 17 of the Melbourne Age.
—A very good report in the Australian, though.

—Was there? I have not read the Australian from cover to cover so I thank the honourable senator for drawing that to my attention. Senator Puplick's policy was reported in the Age. The only things that were reported about Senator Puplick's great policy that was released were the downturns-how the Government might have to move some farmers off marginal land. The Government had better have a big chequebook. A few of the downturns were the only things reported. But we have had these radicals coming into this chamber trying to bring down the farming community of Australia. As Senator Brownhill has said, farming is the most important industry in Australia. Unfortunately, Senator Brownhill underestimated its importance. To put it in context, the farming community provides 50 per cent of our exports rather than the 35 per cent that he quoted. That should be emblazoned on the front pages of newspapers throughout Australia.
—What will it do to our rural exports?
—It will taint our rural exports.
—Order! Senator Boswell should cease interjecting.

—As I was saying, those remarks will be widely reported and there will be no opportunity to refute them. I have said earlier in various debates that I am not afraid of the scientists giving evidence--
—Even soil scientists?

—Even scientists like Senator Sanders. I am not afraid of those. They will be judged by their peers if they make stupid assertions. But when one gets a nut in there, and most followers of the Australian Democrats are nuts--
—Anybody who does not agree with you is a nut.

—I do not say that anyone who does not agree with me is a nut. I have not yet called Senator Cook a nut, and we do not agree very much about gold production. I have not called him a nut yet, but when I do he can pick me up on it.
—You are keeping your options open.

—Right. Those people will be listened to by the media and their comments will be reported. The Government and others will take notice and damage will be done overseas to our exporters, in the same way as the Government has been trying to make a lot of the migration debate.
—What has this to do with the migration debate?

—We are not on the migration debate, but members on the Government side have tried to do us damage by issuing press releases and so on. There is great potential to damage our international trade. I have nothing against continual monitoring of chemicals and experiments to see where they could go wrong in use. But I believe that all arguments-business arguments over rationalisation, or even family arguments-should be confined to the boardroom, or the home. I do not believe that dirty washing should be hung out in public. We will damage our overseas trade by hanging our dirty washing in public. That is what the Australian Democrats want to do. Senator Sanders is supposed to represent Tasmania, but he has done nothing but bring Tasmania down. Every time he speaks in this chamber he decries his country of birth. I repeat that the place for a good argument is inside the home or inside the boardroom. This motion is a further attack on the 55 Australian chemical companies that have produced chemicals for the good of agriculture in Australia and throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I can speak from experience about the use of chemicals in agriculture as I am more familiar with their use in that area than in the veterinary field, dealing with animals. I know that many of the chemicals used in agriculture come from Germany, but Australian companies have developed their own chemicals which are being exported as well as used here and are proving effective. I said that the motion is an attack on the Australian chemical companies. This sort of attack always seems to come from the radicals in this chamber. I shall come now to some points that were made earlier in the debate.

If I remember rightly, Senator Coulter said that he had nothing against the idea of compensation to farmers who were affected by the pesticide problem in beef. I heard him say that and I do not think any Australian Democrats senator would deny it. Where is that provided for in the legislation? The Australian Democrats claim to care and say they represent the underprivileged or the downtrodden in Australia. But when it comes to doing something for the farmers, particularly the beef farmers who are affected in this case, people who are being threatened with bankruptcy because of this problem, where is the sympathy of the Australian Democrats? I understand that in Western Australia alone 130 farmers are still under quarantine. Yet when anyone around the fringes of the capital cities is declared to be underprivileged, the Australian Democrats are the first to jump on the bandwagon and express their sympathy. Why do the Democrats not expand their sympathy beyond the city of Melbourne?

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision is there.

—Show it to me. I have not seen it. I have read Senator Powell's motion from front to back and I cannot find it. When it comes to farmers and agricultural producers where is the charity of the Australian Democrats? I have not heard any member of the Australian Democrats say that Senator Coulter did not say what I said he did. I have spoken to him privately and I do not think he would mind my mentioning it publicly. He admits that he has nothing against having an inquiry into compensation for those who were affected, but I cannot find it in the petition.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before that in Western Australia some of the heat has come off on the subject of bankruptcies. As much as I dislike admitting that any Labor government has done any good anywhere, I must say that the Western Australian Labor Government has done quite a bit to relieve the situation of the farmers who were facing bankruptcy. That Government put a new measure into action only last week.
Next I come to something that Senator Powell said. She mentioned a witch-hunt. If there is any witch-hunt it will be in the inquiry into pesticide residues in beef.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you want.

—That is a new one? When did we have one before? Senator Powell said it was only a witch-hunt into the activities of the departments of agriculture. The departments of agriculture chose to give certain advice and, after all, they employ eminent scientists.
—To get information.

—Yes, all right. As far back as 1977 a scientist, whose name I forget, in the Department of Agriculture in Western Australia made it known to his Director that there could be a problem with DDT residues in beef. Unfortunately, no notice was taken of the warning he gave and the Department went on, without any further inquiry, recommending the use of DDT. Yet the attitude of Senator Powell is that because the matter affects farmers and has a farming background we cannot have an inquiry into the advice that was given out by the Department of Agriculture. So much for the sympathy of the Australian Democrats for the bush. I understand that attitude, because the Australian Democrats have no support in country areas and they admit they are not ever going to get any. I can give a small example. At the polling booth at which I would normally vote in my home town, on the evening of the counting of the poll at the last Federal election there were two votes for the Australian Democrats.
—Did you find them?

—Yes, I am coming to that. There were two votes there out of a total of about 2,000. We did track them down. There were a couple of likely looking Democrats that voted while they were going through on holidays, or something like that. The Democrats fully admit to not having any support in country areas and obviously they are not going to worry about the country people any longer. So much for Senator Powell's sympathy for farmers or anyone else in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Carrying on with the matters I heard during the debate, Senator Powell or some other senator mentioned that the opposition to this inquiry is dying. It is normal to flag something, as certain things have been flagged around this place before. This was flagged in December of last year. Then, hopefully, when the opposition seems to be dying down, the matter is brought on. That has certainly been done in another agricultural debate but I shall not worry about that one. It was mentioned by the Democrats in the debate two days ago that opposition is dying down. To show that is not correct, I would like to quote from two letters. One is from the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia Ltd, dated 18 October 1988, addressed to all senators, Parliament House. It states:

It has come to the attention of this Association that certain implications have been made in Parliament relating to the Australian farm chemical industry's position on the Senate inquiry proposed by the Australian Democrats.
Indeed, I believe it has been suggested that the industry is no longer opposed to the proposed inquiry.
I would like to clarify the industry position and point out that the position has at no stage altered.
Further down the letter states:
This opposition in no way stems from a fear on the part of the industry of what such an inquiry may reveal and in no way implies the industry has `something to hide'.

Rather, the industry firmly believes that the proposed inquiry can achieve very little in the way of positive resolutions for Australian consumers or the the agriculture sector. On the contrary, the inquiry has the potential to cause great harm to Australia's hard-earned reputation as a world leader in the production of `clean' agriculture.

So it goes on. The other letter is from the National Farmers Federation (NFF), which once again, I believe, has been quoted as losing its sting towards opposing this wide-ranging witch-hunt. I hear no cries that I am misquoting the Democrats on this. I do not hear from the two who are present and if any are outside the chamber who reckon I do not know what I am talking about they would have been in here by now. This letter from the NFF is also dated 18 October. The letter which commences with `Dear Sir' states:

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 as the primary consideration. However, as a result of an arrangement between the Australian Democrats and the Government, we now find that we have a cognate debate which includes consideration of the Democrats' motion for a select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. I have to say at the outset that I find it offensive that I am required to debate this Democrats' proposal at a time when we have a serious piece of legislation before us which deserves proper attention and proper support.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we ought to reflect for a moment on the reason that we have both the legislation and the proposal from the Democrats. It will not be forgotten by those who have a care for the rural industry that during 1987, as a result of the diligence of their own testing authorities, the Americans detected in their country some pesticide residues in beef carcasses. Our exports to and our stock in the United States were immediately frozen and a number of properties in Australia were promptly quarantined. As a result, a number of farmers were verging on bankruptcy. When those matters were raised at that time in this Parliament, the coalition supported the industry but, as a result of the contribution of the Democrats and the Government, the cost burden already being borne by the rural sector was substantially increased.

As I look at the speakers list on the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, I am reminded that there is not one single Labor speaker. As I look at the speakers list on the Democrats' motion I notice that, again, there is not one single Labor speaker. I can draw my own conclusions, and I suppose the logic is compelling: the Government has been forced, as a result of a grotty, back-door deal, to support the Democrats' motion, but the Government members have the good sense not to stand up and try to justify themselves in the chamber. We find there is deafening silence from the Government side of the chamber, but we have the two Democrats senators seeking to justify their position and having the absolute audacity to say they have some care, some compassion and some consideration for the rural sector. That hollow claim stands in absolute and stark contrast to their contribution in a tangible and practical way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is hiding behind the Democrats' skirts.

—That is right. The Government is hiding behind the skirts of the Democrats. In 1987, when the residues of the organochlorins were found in beef, the moratorium took place; and I remind honourable senators of the extent of that moratorium. There were 85,000 hectares quarantined in Western Australia alone with the potential of 3.5 million hectares being affected. There were 14,461 beef cattle quarantined with a potential to affect half a million beef cattle. The reflex response from the Government was to upgrade the national residue survey, which until that time had been exclusively funded by the Government, presumably because it provided benefits not only to the rural producers, the shippers, the exporters, the overseas consumers and the domestic consumers but also to everybody, as it was intended to provide certainty about the quality of our beef. But of course it did not because, as the national residue survey was conducted at export abattoirs, nothing was done with the results, except that some domestic beef was processed through these abattoirs and the results were provided to each of the State governments. What was the reaction of each of the State governments? What were their endeavours? Absolutely nothing-except in at least one case there was a suggestion that one State government department had discouraged its producers from having their beef tested for fear that they might find high levels of residue.

SPEECH.PARA: There is evidence to indicate that a number of government departments throughout Australia had prior knowledge of the problem that was confronting the industry at that time. It is clear that in Western Australia there was some knowledge 20 years ago. At that time tests were conducted on sheep grazing in dieldrin affected areas. But that was to have the obvious effect. If Senator Powell had a care for the rural industry, she would understand that of course dieldrin tests on sheep in grazing areas will not show levels of residue, because the absorption of dieldrin and organochlorins into the beast is through the oral consumption of the soil. If she knew anything about the grazing habits of sheep, she would know that they eat the top part of the grass, whereas all cattle consume up to a kilogram of dirt a day as a result of their eating habits. It was found that the residue was residing in the fat of the beef cattle. The endeavours and superficial efforts of Western Australia inevitably came to nought. There are suggestions that there was already knowledge in Queensland. There are suggestions that a random survey of properties on the north coast of New South Wales revealed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Powell might find these statistics boring because they affect the rural industry and not the loonies that she represents; not the harebrained members of society who believe we have to live in an absolute pristine state. Of course it does not interest her. Those random surveys on the north coast of New South Wales indicated that soil on nearly half of all the cane farms was affected and three-quarters of all the banana plantations contained critical levels of dieldrin. Similar levels and degrees of dieldrin were found in most areas of Western Australia. Nothing was done about it. It was of course demonstrated that the national residue survey was an abject failure; in fact, some might describe it as a disgrace, a scandal. What did the Government do about it? It upgraded the quality of the national residue survey and introduced intensive testing. The effect of that was an all-up cost of $11.3m and a once-off annual cost of $1.8m. Who was that cost visited upon? The consumers or taxpayers generally, the shippers, the buyers or the abattoirs? Of course it was not. It was visited upon the farmers. Legislation was promptly introduced into this Parliament levying 15c a head per beast to fund a program which had previously been funded fairly, equitably and reasonably by the Government. That 15c levy was imposed on the farmers because the survey had been found to be an absolute failure. To add to that, in responsible and practical ways the farmers undertook to deal with the problem themselves. In the case of Western Australia, my State, they levied themselves voluntarily to the extent of $3.50 for each beast. That covered the cost of intensive testing and also, in part, the cost of a buy-back program. It needs to be understood that Australia undertook to buy back the beef which had already been bought by the Americans because of the pesticide levels in the beasts.

SPEECH.PARA: So the rural sector, in a responsible way, did everything it could. Its farms were quarantined. Farmers had no immediate ongoing income. They had no capacity to raise funds. They did not have the finances to locate their stock elsewhere. When they asked the Government for help, what did the Government say? It said, `This is a national problem which will be solved by one narrow section of the community', notwithstanding the fact that it was dealing with an industry which represents $2 billion a year in exports, and which allows the Australian people to live at a level to which they have become increasingly accustomed.

The farmers, under those trying and difficult circumstances, had to bring fodder on to their properties at a cost of anything up to $150 a tonne for hay. When they sought to transport stock to unaffected properties they were paying between $13 and $14 per head for an average round trip of 230 to 250 kilometres. They found that, whereas in a very dry season they were able to agist their stock, they were paying $2.50 per beast per week. That did not solve the problem of the calves at foot. So farmers found themselves in a grave and difficult circumstance as a result of dieldrin, DDT, heptachlor, Aldrin and chlordane being found in beef which had been grazing on their properties. I might say that it was not as a result of the beef producers that these organochlorins were there in the first place. In the case of Western Australia they were there because these beef-producing areas had previously been used primarily for the cropping of potatoes. The pesticides had been distributed on those properties at a time when there were potato crops there. The farmers later on either bought the property or converted it for the purpose of beef growing. Without exception, the agriculture department led them to believe that there was no danger, risk or prospect of a health hazard. So, using chemicals which had previously been deemed acceptable by the agricultural department, they then proceeded to farm in the normal fashion, only to be visited some years later with the afflictions of this problem and to find themselves without help, succour or comfort from this cold, cynical Government, aided and abetted by the derelicts who represent themselves by the name of the Australian Democrats.

The farmers were in crisis. They found themselves in difficult circumstances. To add to that, in tandem at that time we had the meat and livestock legislation introduced into the Parliament on 17 December. What was the object of that legislation? It was intended to provide a legislative capacity for the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to levy on every farmer in Australia a further $5 a head to pursue testing for the future. So at every stage, at every step, the farmers found themselves crippled by ongoing costs and without relief. In the case of Western Australia, part of the problem was caused by the State Energy Commission (SEC) spraying dieldrin on its electricity poles through vast tracts of raw agricultural land. I assume that the SEC knew not what it was doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not listen to the nuts who wanted to ban dieldrin!

—If the SEC did not listen to the nuts, it has my unqualified support because listening to the nuts in no way would have helped either the SEC or the farmers. It is interesting that at the time of the debate on these matters the Democrats were not heard from. The genesis of their proposed committee was found amongst the coalition parties. We proposed that an inquiry be conducted into the reasons, causes and effects of chemicals upon stock grazed in certain areas. We were hoping that in the event that it could be identified that the responsibility rested other than with the farmers, some suitable, sensible and reasonable compensation might have been granted to these farmers who found themselves in financial peril.

SPEECH.PARA: But what did we find? The moment we made it public that we were looking at a narrow term of reference for a committee which was intended to provide relief to the rural sector, the Democrats thought, `This is a chance to get the loonies on side'. So they have proposed that a committee be set up with broad terms of reference without exception which do not in any way impinge upon, touch upon or help the rural sector. I ask honourable senators to read the terms of reference of this committee again. Which term of reference of the Democrats' crazy committee will help the rural sector? The answer is none. It is intended to help the bugs and the bears and the beasts of this world. There is nothing about farmers or other human beings.

That is the contribution the Democrats have made. They have made it quite clear that as a result of their grotty little deal with the Government they would not give support to our proposal. As I look at their terms of reference what do I find about compensation? I find nothing. What do I find about an inquiry as to the causes and the reasons for the problems in the rural sector? Absolutely nothing. Of course I find nothing, because the Democrats are not interested in the rural sector. The Democrats could not care less about the rural sector. The rural sector is not part of their fundamental and natural constituency. Do honourable senators know why? It is because people in the rural sector are pretty wise birds. They get up early in the morning. They would not vote for the Democrats if they were the last political party in this chamber.

The rural sector is in an economic crisis for which no relief is provided by the Democrats. The Democrats' proposal bears no relevance to the original proposal put by the Opposition or the legislation that has been introduced by the Government. It in no way analyses the problems of the rural sector. It in no way examines the causes of the failure of the national residue survey. It in no way looks at what might be done for the future. It does absolutely nothing to examine the question of meat inspectors generally. It does nothing to examine the question of inspections and inspection charges at abattoirs, either domestic or export abattoirs. It does absolutely nothing to ensure that there is a proper and effective monitoring at those outlet points. It is simply an inquiry to allow the loonies of this world to give unsubstantiated, incomplete and incompetent evidence which will find its way, because of the bizarre and macabre nature inevitably presented by these people, on to the front page of the daily rags. That is the contribution that the Democrats make to sensible government, responsible decision and a reasoned debate in society. That is their contribution-in the vain hope of getting a bag of votes at the next election.

As a party conceived on the basis of keeping the government and the opposition and the chamber honest and responsible, where do we find them? How would honourable senators like to have that lot looking after their principles or integrity? Of course the Democrats do not have any regard for the rural industry.

The sadness for me is that this proposed inquiry will not simply ignore the rural sector: it will drag itself across the body of an ailing rural sector in which the average family income, if I recall, is about $20,000 a year and where the average individual income is about $11,500 a year. The Democrats will use the rural sector as a chopping block for political expediency. Their intention, if they have to, is to dislocate and cause distress to the rural sector to ensure that our overseas buyers are knocking on the doors of the Government asking, `Is this true? Need we have these concerns? Is it a fact?'. Forever and a day our meat exporters and agricultural departments will be hosing these people down, seeking to satisfy themselves that these outlandish and absurd proposals that will be put to this committee have no substance and foundation.

Yet we find that the Democrats and the Government together are putting this proposal in the way they are. One wonders why this legislation is being considered together with the establishment of a committee. The legislation does, in a responsible way, address the problems of the rural sector. The Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) study reflects concern about the problems in our rural sector. A working party has been set up to consider those matters which, when addressed, will enable the rural sector to conduct itself responsibly with respect to chemicals and their application. There is not a matter I can find in the ASTEC study which will not cover the matters enshrined in the motion proposing a committee, except to say that, instead of having the Democrats asking their crazy friends to come along and give a bit of trivial evidence which afterwards will be tested and found wanting, there will be a committee of eminent scientists contemplating these problems and bringing down in a responsible, measured and sensible way recommendations that will go some way to solving the problems we have before us and answering the so far unanswered questions.

In respect of the legislation, we hear hardly a word from the Democrats. They are not interested in this legislation any more than they were interested in the national residue survey legislation. However, I do respect for a moment the political judgment of one of the Democrats, the senator from Western Australia who crossed the floor and voted with us in disallowing that legislation. She was smart enough to know that that was where the votes were. I do not know whether she understood the dimension of the problem for the rural sector. The rest of the Democrats joined with the Government to load up the rural sector with another 15c per head without regard, care or concern for that sector.

I have noticed in this debate, as I presume we all have, that the Democrats have not laboured this legislation. They have not analysed the legislation. They have not spoken on it, with incidental, inconsequential exception. The Democrats have spoken with regular monotony on their proposal and put aside the matters of major concern. They do not recognise that this legislation deals with some fundamental questions. It seeks to introduce legislation which will provide a scheme for the clearance and use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. It is a scheme that is long overdue and one that I suspect would not have been implemented if it had not been for the problems that visited themselves upon the rural sector last year.

I wonder about the timing of the legislation when I note, for instance, that there are beef farmers in Victoria who are putting together a fighting fund to mount a test case in the Victorian State Supreme Court for compensation for losses arising from the allegedly incorrect advice offered to them by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. A report by the chief manager of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs in that State reveals that departmental officers may have known the effect of persistent organochlorine chemicals in beef as far back as 1971. As I said earlier, similar allegations have been made in other States. In New South Wales a farmer near Kempsey has accused the Department of Agriculture of deliberately withholding information about pesticide residues in the soil.

If those allegations are wrong, what is irrefutable is that during the period of testing the national residue survey information which was flowing from export abattoirs was made available to the various State Government departments of agriculture. I asked myself the question, as I asked the Government previously, `Why was it that when the level of incidence of retained organochlorins in beef cattle in Western Australia was 250 per cent higher than in the rest of Australia there were no bells ringing?' Why did somebody not say after looking at the statistics, `We've clearly got an aberration; we've clearly got a problem. It is a matter which requires research.'?

I can only assume that the statistics were filed away as the problem was thought to be too hard. Had the information, modest and ineffective as perhaps it might have been, been studied and examined it may well have prevented a very real problem for the rural sector. The problem of the rural sector is that the Government chose simply to solve that problem by adding to the cost of the rural sector. The rural sector then quite responsibly and promptly created a voluntary levy scheme for immediate and intensive testing. The result was that 400 tests were conducted in 10 months in Western Australia. Around Australia over 1,300 farms were quarantined. It was not necessary. it was a result of a cover-up or incompetence, or both. The contribution of the Government and the Democrats to that crisis was simply to load the rural sector up with more costs and to create further problems.

As I draw to a close, it is with a tinge of sadness that I note that we have such a serious problem before us and that the rural sector has a serious problem before it. Because this proposal is 10 months old the considered deliberations of the Democrats lead them ultimately not to assist the rural sector but to exacerbate its problems. The Democrats' intention is to get as much free publicity out of their proposal as they possibly can. They will milk this committee for every emotional statement and headline they can possibly get. If it damages our overseas exports and our domestic consumption and if it affects a $2 billion industry, presumably, on the basis of its conduct, so be it. It is hardly a responsible way for a political party in this country to behave. It is hardly preserving and protecting an industry. It does little more than create instability, uncertainty and destabilisation of the industry and a significant part of our economy. One might hope that at the end of the day there will be a deathbed repentance; that the Democrats will recognise the damage they are doing; that the Government will have second thoughts and retreat from the collusion and support it is giving this proposal. But I fear that is a vain hope. I suspect that at the end of the day we will see not only the passing of this legislation-hopefully, with our amendments-but also a corruption of integrity in terms of the ideals which ought to be applied to a sector of our economy, and, sadly, we will see the setting up of this inquiry.

The Senate is currently debating two matters. We are debating principally the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988, and the Government-not the Australian Democrats-has moved a motion which has brought forward for debate cognately a motion by Senator Powell to set up a select committee to examine agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. It is the Government that has brought Senator Powell's motion forward for debate and it is the Government which will be supporting the motion, so it is the Government which will be establishing the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia proposed by Senator Powell.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Opposition parties have taken every step we can to avoid the establishment of that Committee. We opposed as strongly as we could the motion that these matters be debated cognately, that this motion of Senator Powell's come up to be debated with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill. We voted against it, but the motion was supported by all Government senators. Not one Government senator spoke in favour of the proposal that the matters should be debated separately-in other words, that the motion should come on for debate with the Bill-except Senator Cook, who is the Minister with responsibility for the Bill, and all he had to say was that he had heard our arguments against the proposal, he was not satisfied that our arguments were compelling and so the Government would be supporting the Democrats proposal. That is not an argument for it; it is a negative of a negative. So we have not heard from one Government senator the reasons why this motion should be debated cognately with the Bill.

Let me go a step further. In the course of my remarks against that proposal I put two very definite propositions. I put firstly that the reason the Government was supporting the Democrats proposal was that some deal had been done between the Government and the Democrats whereby the Democrats supported some Government measure and in return the Government agreed to push this proposal forward. Having put that general proposition, I went on to put the specific proposition-that it was our belief that the measure the deal was done over was the resource rent tax, and that in exchange for the Democrats' support for the resource rent tax the Government, and in particular Minister Kerin, said, `Yes, we will set up the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia'. I put both of those propositions and said, `Senator Powell will get her opportunity to deny it if it is not true, and Senator Cook on behalf of the Government will get his opportunity to deny it if it is not true'. Neither of them has denied either proposition. Not one word has either of them said about either proposition. It is one of the most aggressive accusations that has ever been made in this chamber-that there was a deal done on votes: `You vote for this measure and we will vote for that measure; blow the farmers of Australia, we don't care about them'. The Government wanted its resource rent tax, which the Democrats had twice voted against, but when the crunch came the Government bought their votes.

I make that accusation now-this is the third time I have made it-and I wait to hear someone deny it on behalf of the Democrats or the Government. It may be that some of the Democrats-I see one in the chamber-may not have been aware of the deal, because I believe it was a confidential deal done between Senator Powell and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. So it may be that some of the Democrats are not aware of it, and certainly some members of the Government are not aware of the deal. It is quite clear that Government senators are absolutely appalled by it. Not one of them has come into this chamber to speak on either the motion that the two matters be debated cognately or the motion to establish a committee. It is clear that Government senators are, as I say, appalled at the proposal to establish this committee. They are not supporting it in any way. There have been no Government speakers in favour of it, but they know that Minister Kerin has locked them into this deal and they cannot get out of it.

The result of this deal is that Australian farmers and Australian primary produce are to be the sacrificial lamb. There will be a public examination of the social and environmental impact of agricultural and veterinary chemicals on primary produce in Australia. I have no doubt there are some chemicals which should not be used in primary production, and of course many have already been banned. I have no doubt that there will be people prepared to give evidence that all chemicals should be banned in primary production, and they will have very strong beliefs as to why they are right. They may be right; I do not know. I do not prejudge the issue. But that would mean action should be taken all around the world. This evidence will be limited and restricted purely to the use of chemicals in Australia, and such evidence will then be blown right around the world to the detriment of Australian primary production and to the detriment of Australian primary producers. I see that the President has now taken the chair, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the Senate briefly on the contribution of scientists in the peace movement and the critical role they are playing in education and technology in this country. When I was at Sydney University as an honours student of English, I heard much from my lecturers about `the two cultures'-science and the humanities-and I was exceedingly frustrated by what was presented to me as an apparently irreconcilable difference between the two. Science was for the boys who studied the world of hard facts within the rigors imposed by empirical discipline. Humanities, on the other hand, was largely for the girls. With only uncertain vocational direction, other than school teaching, we were directed towards the softer subjects to develop our aesthetic, ethical, literary and emotional sensibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not until my honours year that this gap between the two cultures was partially breached for me, largely by a very well read and intellectually stimulating Canadian lecturer. It was she and my fellow students, some of whom had completed a science degree, who exposed me to the history and philosophy of scientific ideas. The effect upon me was profound, something akin to a personal revolution. I began to perceive how damaging to the development of human society was this false dichotomy between science and the humanities, which at university took the form of a very tangible hostility between students from the different faculties. Arts students regarded science students as yobbos, able to deal only with the material world, while arts students were viewed as intellectual snobs; and each was contemptuous of the other. I am pleased that this division has been somewhat eroded at certain Australian universities during the 1970s, although I do not believe we have gone far enough in this direction. When science lecturers begin to quote Shakespeare and Germaine Greer in their lectures and when arts students study the influence of Darwin on literature and culture, we will have begun to heal this educational schizophrenia.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, when I was a student at Sydney University, I came across very few science students in the anti-Vietnam movement. This may have been partly due to the heavy demands of course work and assignments, but it was, I think, one of the subliminal results of our educational system. There was little, if anything, in the education of science students to encourage them to develop political opinions or political involvement. Quite the contrary; they were taught to aspire to some notion of objectivity, much as lawyers are taught, without realising how inherently conservative that notion of objectivity was.

A political conscience cannot be nurtured in a laboratory under conditions of strict scientific method because it involves a value judgment, and that belonged to the arts student whose training, it seemed, was almost entirely directed towards that end. No matter that those judgments were often ill-informed, we made them nonetheless and, in our own way, became as moralistic about, as the science students appeared to be detached from, the political turmoil of the period.

Alongside the new political activism there was the growth of another significant movement in the 1960s-the environment and conservation movement-which in those early days attracted a strong luddite component of which I was never a part. Like many of my fellow students, I was disturbed by the escalating impact of humans on the environment but, as a young feminist caught up in that movement too, I was also conscious of the liberating influence of some technology on women's lives.

Increasingly during this tumultuous period I became aware that my arts education was inadequate in helping me make informed judgments. It was not until several years later in my publishing career that I met another inspired mentor, this time a scientist, who helped me bridge the gap. An American zoologist, this scientist was an early student of Paul Ehrlich and came to Australia in the late 1960s to work as an ecologist, believing that Australia still had some environment left to save. In the late 1970s, together with a second scientist, we co-edited and co-authored a book about Australian ecology for which our long labours were rewarded with a prize from the Royal Australian Zoological Society.

Ecology presented itself as an interdisciplinary study which integrated the physical, biological and social sciences. Essentially a study of processes, it required an interpretive application of mind as well as the capacity to be directly useful not only in describing how human beings were affecting the global environment, but also in proposing ways of minimising that impact for the long term survival of ourselves and the planet. Unlike many of his colleagues at the Museum of Australian who made public statements strictly on the findings of their research, this scientist became quite a controversial figure in expressing strong public opinions on environmental matters. Although he was regarded with dismay by some of his more conservative colleagues, his strong advocacy of conservation issues at local, State and national levels has done much to draw public attention to the significance of loss of wildlife species, the impact of woodchipping in Australian forests, urban pollution, and other matters. Perhaps even more than his considerable scientific ability, I was struck by his great willingness and his ability to communicate not only the findings of his research but also their significance in a social and political context. In this respect, when I first met in 1975, I found him quite unusual.

I have great respect for the work carried out by the organisations, Scientists Against Nuclear Arms (SANA) and Professional Organisations Against Nuclear Arms. SANA was formed some five years ago. It has been particularly useful in producing a regular and very informative newsletter which has done much to publicise the issues and to provide much needed material for a higher level of debate in the peace movement. Like Dr Helen Caldicott, I have an abhorrence of the jargon of the military industrial machine, but we should also recognise that our arguments against the use of nuclear arms will have to be at least as sophisticated and well informed as those who defend them.

First and foremost, because of the special training, education and skills of scientists, it is especially incumbent on them to seek out the facts. Much of the material dealing with, say, the composition and structure of nuclear arms, or the technology of arms verification is highly technical in nature and is not accessible to a lay reader such as myself. I am not able to tell whether a technical expert is fudging the results of his or her research. It is up to members of SANA and other similar organisations to scrutinise the results of scientific research by their peers into various aspects of the nuclear arms race and to draw attention to failures of method or errors in scientific logic. This may involve setting aside time from personal research interests to read scientific journals from overseas, or it may involve contacting colleagues in equivalent organisations abroad for their response to the research under scrutiny.

I do not believe, however, that scientists should limit themselves to the presentation of the facts. Facts do not speak for themselves: they require interpretation-by which I mean they need to be explained. If scientists are going to address an audience other than scientists, which I believe they must, this interpretation must be written or spoken in a language accessible to non-scientists.

The formation of SANA and particularly the publication of Update has done much to present sometimes recondite scientific information to a broader community. Within Australian scientific circles, however, there is still, with some notable exceptions, an academic diffidence about speaking out publicly on certain issues when more than a scientific interpretation is required. This may be due to several reasons. It may be that scientists feel that it is not their role to go beyond the facts and the interpretation of those facts. It may be they lack the confidence that is acquired with an arts education to take a moral stand on controversial issues. It may be an unfamiliarity with the non-scientific language of ethical discourse. It may be academic timidity, a reluctance to expose oneself to criticism from colleagues co-existing in a conservative and circumscribed academic community. It may be a natural and quite understandable distaste for entering the political arena. These are, in my opinion, red herrings.

As the Soviet physicist Anatoly Sakharov has argued, there is a strong moral obligation on scientists to overcome their natural diffidence to participate individually and collectively in this urgent debate on nuclear arms. After all, science produced the atom bomb, and a large proportion of the world's scientists are currently employed in military research of one kind or another. Their position is not neutral or objective: they are actively supporting the arms race. As colleagues, these scientists must be encouraged and persuaded as a group and as individuals to withdraw their labour, much as unions do or as Lysistrata and her consoeurs did in Ancient Greece, and they must be offered constructive alternatives. If a national strike of scientists is not even a remote possibility at this time, at least a national organisation such as SANA could take the Australian Government to task for its particular contribution to the nuclear arms race.

On such matters SANA would need to be able to respond relatively quickly to changes in government policy and this would require a concerted and continuous effort by the organisation to familiarise itself with the details of those policies. This is the laudable aim of the Rainbow alliance, a group consisting largely of Australian social science academics who meet regularly to discuss and analyse government policies on a range of issues, including defence, in the context of hypothetical short term, mid-term and long term goals for Australian society. Having established a national position in relation to a particular government policy, SANA would also need to establish the means of publicising its position. SANA must develop some such strategy in order to establish itself as an organisation with a national voice and not just one preaching to an audience of converted colleagues.

In reading the aims of SANA I am struck by the apparent dissociation of the arms race from what many regard as closely related issues, such as consideration of the opportunity costs of the arms race and military spending. I do not believe that we can have meaningful discussions about ending the arms race unless we address the question of the kind of peace we want.

While reducing the arms race must be the immediate focus of the activities of the peace movement we would be myopic to ignore or avoid an analysis of the causes of war in our society. That must entail a very thorough re-examination of our social, economic and political structures, the distribution of wealth, social justice, sex role stereotyping and conditioning, as well as the continuous re-evaluation of empirical science for all its contribution to modern life. Scientists who are teachers in schools and universities have a very special role to play in this regard. When they stand in front of a class not only are they teaching the facts but also they are helping to shape in their pupils an attitude towards the world. The influence of teachers, while often not immediately acknowledged, can be inestimable in later years. An inspired teacher can influence a human for life and the development of a scientific ethic in young minds will produce a more socially concerned generation of scientists in the future.

I think there are three areas in particular in which concerned scientists could become more active. The first relates to freedom of information (FOI) legislation in Australia. There is a great necessity for the peace movement to develop a more informed and sophisticated debate to counter the proponents of the arms race. Generally, these proponents have at their disposal many more resources than the peace movement because they are intimately associated with governments and military complexes which have billions of dollars at their disposal, not to mention control of huge media conglomerates. These governments and military establishments are paranoically obsessive about secrecy, particularly about nuclear matters, and this is something that should be particularly offensive to scientists as seekers of the facts.

While the United States of America sends its nuclear aids-bearing ships to Australian shores it must also be recognised that it provides much of the information that we in the peace movement need to wage our war of words. This information is obtained under the considerably more liberal FOI legislation that exists in the United States. SANA could very usefully lobby the Federal Government to relax its freedom of information legislation and press at the State level for wide-ranging FOI Acts. We need more information rather than less.

With the great respect accorded to scientists in our community, SANA members could consider taking on the argument of national security-a common reason given for denying access to information-as well as pointing out the folly of accepting the secrecy provisions of foreign powers, for example, in relation to the United States and United Kingdom policies of neither confirming nor denying the presence of weapons on board their ships.

The second area in which organisations such as SANA could become more active is in its dissemination of information to the active unions in the peace movement, particularly the waterfront unions, which are in the front line of a nuclear accident should it occur. I believe that the unions would welcome such an approach and I believe that scientists would also benefit from hearing about the difficulties the unions face, both on site and in taking a stand on peace issues. It is vital that we forge links widely in the peace movement in order to develop a broad base of support for peace and disarmament issues.

A third initiative is for organisations such as SANA to become actively involved with the soon to be established Australian science and technology information service, a science information service developed by science broadcaster Peter Pockley and the Australian Academy of Science for journalists, politicians and schools. This may provide a significant means of promulgating correct information about the arms race to the media, to parliamentarians and to students.

In closing, let me commend the excellent work of SANA, Professional Organisations Against Nuclear Arms, the Medical Association for Prevention of War and other similar organisations in the past. I encourage them to continue to take an active role in the Australian peace movement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

(2) Of these 140 received, 107 cases were accepted by the Australian Customs Service and formal investigations initiated. These 107 cases represent 47 commodities.

(3) These commodities were: Almonds, Audio Tape imported in Jumbo Webs or Pancakes, Castors, Ceiling Sweep Fans, Cement Clinker, Cement, Portland, Chains and Fittings, Alloy Steel, Chains, Alloy Steel, Cheese, Edam, Dental Furniture, Dichlorophenoxyacetic Acid, Electric Motor Parts, Electric Winches, Ethyl Acetate, Ethylene Glycol Monobutyl Ether, Fabric, Worsted Woven, Fork Lift Trucks, Frozen Peas, Ham, Canned, Hydraulic Brake Fluid, Hypodermic Needles, Industrial Nitrocellulose, Iron & Steel, Cold Rolled Hoop, Strip, Sheet, Coil, Iron & Steel, Galvanised Hoop, Strip, Sheet, Coil, Lamps, Electric Filament, Levamisole Hydrochloride. Linear Alkylbenzene Sulphonic Acid, Monoethylene Glycol, Multi-Tyred Rollers, Nylon (Polyamide) Yarn, Orange Juice, Frozen Concentrated, Out Front Mowers, Paper, Sublimation Transfer Printing, Passenger Car Tyres, Pencils, Coloured Pencils, Coloured & Lead, Pigments, Lushed Polyethylene, Low Density Polyols, Propylene Oxide Based Polyether, PVC Homopolymer, PVC Sheet, Rigid Thermoforming Grade, Unplasticised, Reflective Aluminium Foil, Ring Mechanisms for Loose Leaf Binders, Silicone Sealants, Stainless Steel Flat Products, Urea, Video Cassette Tapes.

20 still under investigation-Audio Tape Jumbo Webs and Pancakes from Korea; Cement Clinker from Korea; Cement, Portland, from Japan; Electric Motor Parts from Taiwan; Fork Lift Trucks from Japan; Ham, Canned, from the Netherlands; Levamisole Hydrochloride from Belgium, China, Germany, Hong Kong, Singapore and Switzerland; Multi-Tyred Rollers from Czechoslovakia; Pencils, Coloured, from Hungary and Poland; Pencils, Coloured and Lead, from Brazil; Urea from New Zealand; Video Cassette Tapes from Hong Kong, Japan and Korea.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: How will conflicts of interests be resolved under the new coastal surveillance arrangements in respect of:
(b) different requirements of Quarantine, Customs, Immigration and Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
